encodingDesc.p: The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Alice Valentine Hylas Mary Cellide Francis Old Sebastian Launcelot Thomas Dorothea Sam First Physician Second Physician Third Physician Servant Fiddler Michael Maid Sailor Moor Abbess First Nun Second Nun multiple

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: How dearly welcome you are!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I know it,
And my best sister, you are as dear to my sight,
And pray let this confirm it, how you have governed
My poor state in my absence, how my servants,
I dare, and must believe, else I should wrong ye,
The best and worthiest.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: As my woman's wit Sir,
Which is but weak and crazy.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: But good Alice
Tell me how fares the gentle Cellide,
The life of my affection, since my travel,
My long and lazy travel? is her love still
Upon the growing hand? does it not stop
And wither at my years? has she not viewed
And entertained some younger smooth behaviour,
Some youth but in his blossom, as herself is?
There lies my fears.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: They need not, for believe me
So well you have managed her, and won her mind,
Even from her hours of childhood, to this ripeness,
And in your absence, that by me enforced still,
So well distilled your gentleness into her,
Observed her, fed her fancy, lived still in her,
And though Love be a boy, and ever youthful,
And young, and beauteous objects ever aimed at,
Yet here ye have gone beyond love, bettered nature,
Made him appear in years, in gray years fiery,
His bow at full bent ever: fear not brother,
For though your body has been far off from her,
Yet every hour your heart, which is your goodness,
I have forced into her, won a place prepared too,
And willingly to give it ever harbour;
Believe she is so much yours, and won by miracle,
(Which is by age) so deep a stamp set on her
By your observances, she cannot alter,
Were the child living now ye lost at sea
Among the Genoway Galleys, what a happiness,
What a main blessing?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O no more good sister,
Touch no more that string, it is too harsh and jarring.
With that child all my hopes went, and you know
The root of all those hopes, the mother too
Within few days.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: It is too true, and too fatal,
But peace be with their souls.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I hope the beauteous Cellide.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: You may Sir,
For all she is, is yours.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: For the poor boys loss,
I have brought a noble friend, I found in travel,
A worthier mind, and a more temperate spirit
If I have so much judgment to discern them,
Man yet was never master of.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: What is he?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: A Gentleman, I do assure myself,
And of a worthy breeding, though he hide it:
I found him at Valentia, poor and needy,
Only his mind the master of a treasure.
I sought his friendship, won him by much violence,
His honesty and modesty still fearing
To thrust a charge upon me; how I love him,
He shall now know, where want and he hereafter
Shall be no more companions: use him nobly,
It is my will, good sister, all I have
I make him free companion in, and partner,
But only

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: I observe ye, hold your right there,
Love and high rule allows no rivals, brother,
He shall have fair regard, and all observance.

sp.speaker: Hylas.
sp.l: Ye are welcome noble Sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What, Monsieur Hylas!
I am glad to see your merry body well yet.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: In faith ye are welcome home; what news beyond seas?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: None, but new men expected, such as you are,
To breed new admirations: it is my sister,
Pray ye know her sir.

sp.speaker: Hylas.
sp.l: With all my heart; your leave Lady.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: Ye have it Sir.

sp.speaker: Hylas.
sp.l: A shrewd smart touch, which does prognosticate
A body keen and active, somewhat old,
But that is all one: age brings experience
And knowledge to dispatch. I must be better
And nearer in my service, with your leave sir,
To this fair Lady.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What, the old squire of dames still?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Still the admirer of their goodness: with all my heart now
I love a woman of her years, a pacer
That lays the bridle in her neck will travel
Forty, and somewhat fulsome is a fine dish,
These young colts; are too skittish.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: My cousin Mary
In all her joy Sir to congratulate
Your fair return.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: My loving, and kind cousin,
A thousand welcomes.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: A thousand thanks to heaven Sir,
For your safe, voyage, and return.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I thank ye:
But where is my blessed Cellide? her slackness
In visitation.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: Think not so, dear Uncle,
I left her on her knees, thanking the gods
With tears and prayers.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Ye have given me too much comfort.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: She will not be long from ye.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Your fair cousin?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: It is so, and a bait you cannot balk sir,
If your old rule reign in you, ye may know her
A happy stock ye have, right worthy Lady,
The poorest of your servants, vows his duty
And obliged faith.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: O it is a kiss you would sir,
Take it, and tie your tongue up.

sp.speaker: Hylas.
sp.l: I am an ass
I do perceive now: a blind ass, a blockhead:
For this is handsomeness, this that that draws us,
Body and bones: o what a mounted forehead,
What eyes and lips, what everything about her?
How like a Swan she swims her pace, and bears
Her silver breasts? this is the woman, she,
And only she, that I will so much honour
As to think worthy of my love, all older Idols
I heartily abhor, and give to gunpowder,
And all complexions besides hers, to Gypsies.

div2.stage: Enter Francis at one door, and Cellide at another.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O my dear life, my better heart, all dangers,
Distresses in my travel, all misfortunes,
Had they been endless like the hours upon me,
In this kiss, had been buried in oblivion:
How happy have ye made me, truly happy?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: My joy has so much over-mastered me,
That in my tears for your return.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O dearest:
My noble friend too: what a blessedness
Have I about me now? how full my wishes
Are come again, a thousand hearty welcomes
I once more lay upon ye: all I have,
The fair and liberal use of all my servants
To be at your command, and all the uses
Of all within my power.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Ye are too munificent,
Nor am I able to conceive those thanks sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Ye wrong my tender love now, even my service,
Nothing accepted, nothing stuck between us
And our entire affections but this woman,
This I beseech ye friend.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: It is a jewel
I do confess, would make a thief, but never
Of him that is so much yours, and bound your servant,
That were a base ingratitude.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Ye are noble,
Pray be acquainted with her, keep your way sir,
My cousin and my sister.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: Ye are most welcome:

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: If anything in our poor powers fair sir,
To render ye content, and liberal welcome
May but appear, command it.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: Ye shall find us
Happy in our performance.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: The poor servant
Of both your goodnesses presents his service.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Come, no more complement: custom has made it
Dull, old, and tedious: ye are once more welcome,
As your own thoughts can make ye, and the same ever.
And so we will in to ratify it.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Hark ye, Valentine:
Is wild oats yet come over?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Yes: with me Sir.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: How does he bear himself?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: A great deal better:
Why do you blush? the Gentleman will do well.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: I should be glad on it Sir

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: How does his father?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: As mad a worm as ever he was.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I looked for it:
Shall we enjoy your company?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: I will wait on ye:
Only a thought, or two.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: We bar all prayers.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: This last wench, Aye this last wench was a fair one:
A dainty Wench, a right one; a devil take it,
What do I ail; to have fifteen now in liking
Enough a man would think to stay my stomach,
But what is fifteen, or fifteen score to my thoughts?
And wherefore are mine eyes made, and have lights,
But to increase my objects? this last wench
Sticks plaguey close unto me: a hundred pound
I were as close to her: If I loved now
As many foolish men do, I should run mad.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Sirrah, no more of your French shrugs I advise you,
If you be lousy, shift yourself.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: May it please your worship:

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Only to see my son, my son, good Launcelot;
Your Master, and my son; Body-o-me Sir,
No money, no more money, Monsieur Launcelot,
Not a denier, sweet Seignior: bring the person,
The person of my boy, my boy Tom, Monsieur Thomas,
Or get you gone again, du gata whee, Sir;
Bassa mi cu, good Launcelot, valetote.
My boy, or nothing.

sp.speaker: Laun.
sp.l: Then to answer punctually.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I say to the purpose,

sp.speaker: Laun.
sp.l: Then I say to the purpose,
Because your Worships vulgar understanding
May meet me at the nearest: your son, my master,
Or Monsieur Thomas, (for so his travel stiles him)
Through many foreign plots that virtue meets with,
And dangers (I beseech ye give attention)
Is at the last arrived
To ask your (as the French man calls it sweetly)
Benediction de jour en jour.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Sirrah, do not conjure me with your French furies.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Che ditt' a vou, Monsieur.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Che doga vou, Rascal:
Leave me your rotten language, and tell me plainly
And quickly, sirrah, lest I crack your French crown,
What your good Master means: I have maintained
You and your Monsieur, as I take it, Launcelot,
These two years at your ditty vous, your jours:
Jour me no more, for not another penny
Shall pass my purse.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Your Worship is erroneous,
For as I told you, your Son Tom, or Thomas,
My Master, and your son is now arrived
To ask ye, as our language bears it nearest
Your quotidian blessing, and here he is in person.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: What Tom, boy, welcome with all my heart boy,
Welcome in faith thou hast gladded me at soul boy,
Infinite glad I am, I have prayed too, Thomas
For you wild Thomas, Tom, I thank thee heartily
For coming home.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Sir, I do find your prayers
Have much prevailed above my sins.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: How is this?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Else certain I had perished with my rudeness,
Ere I had won myself to that discretion
I hope you shall hereafter find.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Humph, Humph,
Discretion? is it come to that? the boy is spoiled.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Sirrah, you rogue, look for it, for I will make thee
Ten times more miserable than thou thoughtest thyself
Before thou travelledest: thou hast told my father
I know it, and I find it, all my rogueries
By mere way of prevention to undo me.

sp.speaker: Laun.
sp.l: Sir, as I speak eight languages, I only
Told him you came to ask his benediction,
De jour en jour.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: But that I must be civil,
I would beat thee like a dog: sir, howsoever
The time I have misspent may make you doubtful,
Nay, harden your belief against my conversion,

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: A pox on travel, I say.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Yet dear father
Your own experience in my after courses.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Prithee no more; it is scurvy; there is thy sister
Undone without redemption: he eats with picks
Utterly spoiled, his spirit baffled in him.
How have I sinned that this affliction
Should light so heavy on me. I have no more sons;
And this no more mine own, no spark of nature
Allows him mine now, he is grown tame: my grand curse
Hang over his head that thus transformed thee: travel?
I will send my horse to travel next; oui monsieur,
Now will my most canonical dear neighbours
Say I have found my son, and rejoice with me
Because he has mewed his mad tricks off. I know not,
But I am sure, this Monsieur, this fine gentleman
Will never be in my books like mad Thomas,
I must go seek an heir, for my inheritance
Must not turn secretary: my name and quality
Has kept my land three hundred years in madness,
If it slip now, may it sink.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Excellent Sister,
I am glad to see thee well: but where is thy father?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Gone discontent, it seems.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: He did ill in it
As he does all; for I was uttering
A handsome speech or two, I have been studying
Ever since I came from Paris: how glad to see thee?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I am gladder to see you, with more love too
I dare maintain it, than my father is sorry
To see (as he supposes) your conversion:
And I am sure he is vexed, nay more I know it,
He has prayed against it mainly: but it appears sir
Ye had rather blind him with that poor opinion,
Than in yourself correct it, dearest brother,
Since there is in our uniform resemblance,
No more to make us two, but our bare sexes;
And since one happy Birth produced us hither,
Let one more happy mind.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: It shall be sister,
For I can do it when I list: and yet wench,
Be mad too when I please: I have the trick on it:
Beware a traveller.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Leave that trick too.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Not for the world: but where is my Mistress
And prithee say how does she? I melt to see her,
And presently: I must away.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Then do so,
For on my faith, she will not see your brother.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Not see me? I will.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Now you play your true self;
How would my father love this! I will assure ye
She will not see you; she has heard, (and loudly)
The gambols that you played since your departure,
In every Town ye came, your several mischiefs,
Your rouses, and your wenches: all your quarrels,
And the no causes of them: these I take it
Although she love ye well, to modest ears,
To one that waited for your reformation,
To which end travel was propounded by her Uncle,
Must needs, and reason for it, be examined,
And by her modesty, and feared too light too
To file with her affections: ye have lost her
For anything I see, exiled yourself.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: No more of that, sweet Doll, I will be civil.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: But how long?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Wouldst thou have me lose my birth-right?
For yond old thing will disinherit me
If I grow too demure: good sweet Doll, prithee:
Prithee dear sister, let me see her.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Nay, I beseech thee: by this light.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Aye: swagger.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Kiss me, and be my friend, we two were twins,
And shall we now grow strangers?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: It is not my fault.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Well, there be other women, and remember
You, you were the cause of this: there be more lands too,
And better People in them, fare ye well,
And other loves: what shall become of me
And of my vanities, because they grieve ye?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Come hither, come, do you see that cloud that flies there?
So light are you, and blown with every fancy:
Will ye but make me hope ye may be civil?
I know your nature is sweet enough, and tender,
Not grated on, nor curbed: do you love your Mistress?

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: He lies, that says I do not.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Would ye see her?

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: If you please: for it must be so.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: And appear to her
A thing to be beloved?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Change then
A little of your wildness into wisdom,
And put on a more smoothness:
I will do the best I can to help ye, yet
I do protest she swore, and swore it deeply,
She would never see you more; where is your man's heart now?
What do you faint at this?

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: She is a woman:
But he she entertains next for a servant,
I shall be bold to quarter.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: No thought of fighting;
Go in, and there we will talk more, be but ruled,
And what lies in my power, ye shall be sure of.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: He cannot be so wild still.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: It is most certain,
I have now heard all, and all the truth.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Grant all that;
Is he the first, that has been given a lost man,
And yet come fairly home? he is young, and tender
And sit for that impression; your affections
Shall stamp upon him, age brings on discretion,
A year hence, these mad toys that now possess him
Will show like bugbears to him, shapes to fright him;
Marriage dissolves all these like mists.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: They are grounded
Hereditary in him, from his father
And to his grave they will haunt him.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: It is your fear
Which is a wise part in you; yet your love
However you may seem to lessen it
With these dislikes, and choke it with these errors,
Do what you can will break out to excuse him,
Ye have him in your heart, and planted, Cousin,
From whence the power of reason, nor discretion
Can ever root him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Planted in my heart Aunt?
Believe it no, I never was so liberal:
What though he show a so so comely fellow
Which we call pretty? or say it may be handsome?
What though his promises may stumble at
The power of goodness in him, sometimes use too?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: How willingly thy heart betrays thee cousin?
Cozen thyself no more: thou hast no more power
To leave off loving him, than he that is thirsty
Has to abstain from drink standing before him;
His mind is not so monstrous for his shape
If I have eyes; I have not seen his better.
A hansom brown complexion

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Reasonable
Inclining to a tawny.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Had I said so
You would have wished my tongue out: then his making.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Which may be mended: I have seen legs straighter,
And cleaner made.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: A body too,

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Far neater,
And better set together.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: God forgive thee,
For against thy conscience thou liest stubbornly.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I grant it is neat enough.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: It is excellent,
And where the outward parts are fair and lovely,
(Which are but molds on the mind) what must the soul be?
Put case youth has his swinge, and fiery nature
Flames to mad uses many times.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: All this
You only use, to make me say I love him:
I do confess I do, but that my fondness
Should fling itself upon his desperate follies.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: I do not counsel that, see him reclaimed first,
Which will not prove a miracle, yet Mary,
I am afraid it will vex thee horribly
To stay so long.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: No, no Aunt, no, believe me.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: What was your dream tonight? for I observed ye
Hugging of me; with good, dear, sweet Tom.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: Fie Aunt,
Upon my conscience.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: On my word it is true wench:
And then ye kissed me Mary, more than once too,
And sighed, and O sweet Tom again: nay, do not blush,
Ye have it at the heart wench.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I will be hanged first,
But you must have your way.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: And so will you too,
Or break down hedges for it. Dorothea,
The welcomest woman living: how does thy brother?
I hear he is turned a wondrous civil gentleman
Since his short travel.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Pray Heaven he make it good Alice.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: How do ye friend, I have a quarrel to ye,
Ye stole away, and left my company.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: O pardon me, dear friend, it was to welcome
A brother, that I have some cause to love well.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Prithee how is he? thou speakest truth.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Not perfect:
I hope he will be.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Never: he has forgot me,
I hear wench, and his hot love too:

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: Thou wouldst howl then.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And I am glad it should be so; his travels
Have yielded him variety of Mistresses,
Fairer in his eye far.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: O cogging rascal.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: I was a fool, but better thoughts I thank heaven.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Pray do not think so, for he loves you dearly,
Upon my troth most firmly, would fain see you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: See me friend? do you think it fit?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: It may be,
Without the loss of credit too: he is not
Such a prodigious thing, so monstrous,
To fling from all society.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: He is so much contrary
To my desires, such an antipathy
That I must sooner see my grave.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Dear friend,
He was not so before he went.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I grant it,
For then I daily hoped his fair conversion.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: Come, do not mask yourself, but see him freely,
Ye have a mind.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: That mind I will master then.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: And is your hate so mortal?

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: Not to his person,
But to his qualities, his mad-cap follies,
Which still like Hydras heads grow thicker on him.
I have a credit friend, and maids of my sort,
Love where their modesties may live untainted.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I give up that hope then: pray for your friends sake,
If I have any interest within ye,
Do but this courtesy, accept this Letter.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: From him?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: The same; it is but a minutes reading,
And as we look on shapes of painted devils,
Which for the present may disturb our fancy,
But with the next new object lose them, so
If this be soul, ye may forget it, pray.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Have ye seen it, friend?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I will not lie; I have not,
But I presume, so much he honours you,
The worst part of himself was cast away
When to his best part he writ this.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: For your sake,
Not that I any way shall like his scribbling.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: A shrewd dissembling quean.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I thank ye, dear friend,
I know she loves him.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: Yes, and will not lose him,
Unless he leap into the Moon, believe that,
And then she will scramble too: young wenches loves
Are like the course of quarerns, they may shift
And seem to cease sometimes, and yet we see
The least distemper pulls them back again,
And seats them in their old course; fear her not,
Unless he be a devil.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Now heaven bless me.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: What has he writ?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Out, out upon him.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Ha, what has the mad man done?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Worse, worse, and worse still.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: Some northern toy, a little broad.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Still fowler?
Hey, hey Boys, goodness keep me: o?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: What ail ye?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Here, take your spell again, it burns my fingers.
Was ever Lover writ so sweet a Letter,
So elegant a style: pray look upon it:
The rarest inventory of rank oaths
That ever cut-purse cast.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: What a mad boy is this?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: A little julep gently sprinkled over
To cool his mouth, lest it break out in blisters,
Indeed law. Yours forever.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I am sorry.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You shall be welcome to me, come when you please,
And ever may command me virtuously,
But for your brother, you must pardon me,
Till I am of his nature, no access friend,
No word of visitation, as ye love me,
And so for now I will leave ye.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: What a letter
Has this thing written, how it roars like thunder?
With what a state he enters into stile.
Dear Mistress.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Out upon him bedlam.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: Well, there be ways to reach her yet: such likeness
As you two carry methinks.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I am mad too,
And yet can apprehend ye: fare ye well,
The fool shall now fish for himself.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: Be sure then
His tough be tith and strong: and next no swearing,
He will catch no fish else, Farewell Doll.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Farewell Alice.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Indeed he is much changed, extremely altered,
His colour faded strangely too.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: The air,
The sharpe and nipping air of our new climate
I hope is all, which will as well restore
To health again the affected body by it,
And make it stronger far, as leave it dangerous;
How does my sweet, our blessed hour comes on now
Apace my Cellide, (it knocks at door)
In which our loves, and long desires like rivers
Rising asunder far, shall fall together,
Within these two days dear.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: When heaven, and you sir
Shall think it fit: for by your wills I am governed,

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: It were good some preparation.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: All that may be:
It shall be no blind wedding: and all the joy
Of all our friends I hope: he looks worse hourly,
How does my friend, myself? he sweats too coldly,
His pulse, like the slow dropping of a spout,
Scarce gives his function: how is it man, alas sir,
You look extreme ill: is it any old grief,
The weight of which?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: None, gentle Sir, that I feel,
Your love is too too tender.
Nay believe sir,

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: You cannot be the master of your health,
Either some fever lies in wait to catch ye,
Whose harbinger is already in your face
We see preparing: or some discontent,
Which if it lie in this house, I dare say
Both for this noble Gentleman, and all
That live within it, shall as readily
Be purged away, and with as much care softened,
And where the cause is.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: It is a joy to be ill,
Where such a virtuous fair Physician
Is ready to relieve: your noble cares
I must, and ever shall be thankful for,
And would my service (I dare not look upon her).
But be not fearful, I feel nothing dangerous,
A grudging caused by the alteration
Of air, may hang upon me: my heart is whole,
(I would it were.)

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I knew the cause to be so.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: No, you shall never know it.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: Some warm broths
To purge the blood, and keep your bed a day Sir,
And sweat it out.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I have such cordials;
That if you will but promise me to take them,
Indeed you shall be well, and very quickly,
I will be your Doctor, you shall see how finely
I will fetch ye up again.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: He sweats extremely:
Hot, very hot: his pulse beats like a drum now,
Feel Sister, feel, feel sweet.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: How that touch stung me?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: My gown there.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: And those juleps in the window.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: Some see his bed made.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: This is most unhappy,
Take courage man, it is nothing but an ague.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: And this shall be the last fit.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Not by thousands:
Now what it is to be truly miserable,
I feel at full experience.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: He grows fainter.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Come, lead him in, he shall to bed: a vomit,
I will have a vomit for him.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: A purge first,
And if he breathed a vein.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No, no, no bleeding,
A Clyster will cool all.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: Be of good cheer Sir.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: He is loath to speak.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: How hard he holds my hand Aunt?

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: I do not like that sign.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Away to his chamber,
Softly, he is full of pain, be diligent
With all the care ye have: would I had excused him.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Why do you rail at me? do I dwell in her
To force her to do this or that? your Letter,
A wildfire on your Letter; your sweet Letter;
You are so learned in your writs: ye stand now
As if ye had worried sheep: you must turn tippet,
And suddenly, and truly, and discreetly
Put on the shape of order and humanity,
Or you must marry Malkyn the May Lady:
You must, dear Brother: do you make me carrier
Of your confound-mes, and your culverings?
Am I a seemly agent for your oaths?
Who would have writ such a debauched?

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Your patience,
May not a man profess his Love?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: In blasphemies?
Rack a maids tender ears, with damns and devils?

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Out, out upon thee.
how would you have me write?
Begin with my love premised? surely,
And by my truly Mistress

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Take your own course
For I see all persuasion is lost upon ye:
Humanity, all drowned: from this hour fairly

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I will wash my hands of all ye do: farewell Sir.
Thou art not mad?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: No, if I were, dear brother
I would keep you company: get a new Mistress
Some suburb Sant, that six pence, and some others
Will draw to parley: carouse her health in Cans
And candles ends, and quarrel for her beauty,
Such a sweet heart must serve your turn: your old love
Releases ye of all your ties; disclaims ye
And utterly abjures your memory
Till time has better managed ye, will ye command me

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: What bobbed of all sides?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Any worthy service
Unto my father sir, that I may tell him
Even to his peace of heart, and much rejoicing
Ye are his true son Thom still? will it please ye
To beat some half a dozen of his servants presently,
That I may testify you have brought the same faith
Unblemished home, ye carried out? or if it like you
There be two chambermaids within, young wenches,
Handsome and apt for exercise: you have been good, sir,
And charitable though I say it Seignior
To such poor orphans: and now, by the way I think on it
Your young rear Admiral, I mean your last bastard
Don John, ye had by Lady Blanch the Dairy Maid,
Is by an Academy of learned Gypsies,
Foreseeing some strange wonder in the infant
Stolen from the Nurse, and wanders with those Prophets.
There is plate in the parlour, and good store Sir,
When your wants shall supply it. So most humbly
(First rendering my due service) I take leave sir.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Why Doll, why Doll I say: my letter fubbed too,
And no access without I mend my manners?
All my designs in Limbo? I will have her,
Yes, I will have her, though the devil roar,
I am resolved that, if she live above ground,
I will not be bobbed in the nose with every bobtail:
I will be civil too: now I think better,
Exceeding civil, wondrous finely carried:
And yet be mad upon occasion,
And stark mad too, and save my land: my father:
I will have my will of him, however my wench goes.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Sirrah, I say still you have spoiled your Master: leave your stitches:
I say thou hast spoiled thy Master.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: I say how sir?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Marry thou hast taught him like an arrant rascal,
First to read perfectly: which on my blessing
I warned him from: for I knew if he read once,
He was a lost man. Secondly, Sir Launcelot,
Sir lousy Launcelot, ye have suffered him
Against my power first, then against my precept,
To keep that simpering sort of people company,
That sober men call civil: mark ye that Sir?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: If it please your worship.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: It does not please my worship,
Nor shall not please my worship: thirdly and lastly,
Which if the law were here, I would hang thee for,
(However I will lame thee) like a villain,
Thou hast wrought him
Clean to forget what it is to do a mischief,
A handsome mischief, such as thou knewest I loved well.
My servants all are sound now, my drink soured,
Not a horse pawned, nor played away: no warrants
Come for the breach of peace.
Men travel with their money, and nothing meets them:
I was accursed to send thee, thou wert ever
Leaning to laziness, and loss of spirit,
Thou sleptest still like a cork upon the water,
Your worship knows, I ever was accounted
The most debauched, and please you to remember,
Every day drunk too, for your worships credit,
I broke the Butlers head too.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: No base Palliard,
I do remember yet that onslaught, thou wast beaten,
And fleddest before the Butler; a black jack
Playing upon thee furiously, I saw it:
I saw thee scattered rogue, behold thy Master.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: What sweet content dwells here?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Put up your book sir,
We are all undone else.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Tom, when is the horse-race?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: I know not Sir.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: You will be there?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Not I Sir,
I have forgot those journeys.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Spoiled forever,
The cocking holds at Derby, and there will be
Jack Wild-oats, and Will Purser.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I am sorry sir,
They should employ their time so slenderly,
Their understandings will bear better courses.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Yes, I will marry again: but Monsieur Thomas,
What say ye to the Gentleman that challenged ye
Before he went, and the fellow ye fell out with?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: O good Sir,
Remember not those follies; where I have wronged sir,
(So much I have now learned to discern myself)
My means, and my repentance shall make even,
Nor do I think it any imputation
To let the Law persuade me.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Any woman:
I care not of what colour, or complexion,
Any that can bear children: rest ye merry.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Ye have utterly undone: clean discharged me,
I am for the ragged regiment.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Eight languages,
And wither at an old man's words?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: O pardon me.
I know him but too well: eight score I take it
Will not keep me from beating, if not killing:
I will give him leave to break a leg, and thank him:
You might have saved all this, and sworn a little.
What had an oath or two been? or a head broke,
Though it had been mine, to have satisfied the old man?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I will break it yet.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Now it is too late, I take it:
Will ye be drunk tonight, (a less entreaty
Has served your turn) and save all yet? not mad drunk,
For then ye are the devil, yet the drunker,
The better for your father still: your state is desperate,
And with a desperate cure ye must recover it:
Do something, do Sir: do some drunken thing,
Some mad thing, or some anything to help us.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Go for a Fiddler then: the poor old Fiddler
That says his songs: but first where lies my Mistress,
Did ye enquire out that?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: In the Lodge, alone sir,
None but her own attendants.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: It is the happier:
Away then, find this Fiddler, and do not miss me
By nine o'clock.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Via.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: My Father is mad now,
And ten to one will disinherit me:
I will put him to his plunge, and yet be merry.
What Ribaldry?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Don Thomasio.
De bene venew.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I do embrace your body:
How dost thou Sam?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: The same Sam still: your friend Sir.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: And how is it bouncing boys?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Thou art not altered,
They said thou wert all Monsieur.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: O believe it,
I am much altered, much another way:
The civilest Gentleman in all your Country:
Do not ye see me altered? ye, and nay Gentlemen,
A much converted man: where is the best wine boys?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: A sound Convertite.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: What, hast thou made up twenty yet?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Byrlady,
I have given a shrewd push at it, for as I take it,
The last I fell in love with, scored sixteen.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Look to your skin, Rambaldo the sleeping Giant
Will rouse and rent thee piece-meal.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: He never perceives them
Longer than looking on.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Thou never meanest then
To marry any that thou lovest?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: No surely,
Nor any wise man I think; marriage?
Would you have me now begin to be prentice,
And learn to cobble other men's old boots?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Why, you may take a Maid.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Where? can you tell me?
Or if it were possible I might get a Maid,
To what use should I put her? look upon her,
Dandle her upon my knee, and give her sugar sops?
All the new gowns in the Parish will not please her,
If she be high bred, for there is the sport she aims at,
Nor all the feathers in the Friars.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Then take a widow,
A good stanch wench, that tith.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: And begin a new order,
Live in a dead man's monument, not I Sir,
I will keep mine own road, a true mendicant:
What pleasure this day yields me, I never covet
To lay up for the morrow; and methinks ever
Another man's cook dresses my diet neatest.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Thou wast wont to love old women, fat, and flat nosed,
And thou wouldst say they kissed like Flounders, flat
All the face over.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: I have had such damsels
I must confess.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Thou hast been a precious rogue.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Only his eyes; and on my conscience
They lie with half the Kingdom.

div2.stage: Enter over the Stage, Physitians and others.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: What is the matter?
Whither go all these-men menders, these Physicians?
Whose Dog lies sick of the mulligrubs?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: O the Gentleman,
The young smug Seignior, Master Valentine
Brought out of travel with him, as I hear,
Is fallen sick on the sudden, desperate sick,
And likely they go thither.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Who? young Frank?
The only tempered spirit, Scholar, Soldier,
Courtier: and all in one piece? it is not possible.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: there is one can better satisfy you.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Mistress Alice,
I joy to see you, Lady.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: Good Monsieur Thomas,
You are welcome from your travel: I am hasty,
A Gentleman lies sick Sir.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: And how dost thou?
I must know, and I will know.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: Excellent well,
As well as may be, thank ye.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: I am glad on it,
And prithee hark.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: I cannot stay.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: A while Alice.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Never look so narrowly, the mark is in her mouth still.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: I am looking at her legs, prithee be quiet.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: I cannot stay.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: O sweet Alice.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: A clean instep,
And that I love a-life: I did not mark
This woman half so well before, how quick
And nimble like a shadow, there her leg showed:
By the mass a neat one, the colour of her stocking,
A much inviting colour.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: My good Monsieur,
I have no time to talk now.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Pretty Breeches,
Finely becoming too.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: By heaven.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: She will not,
I can assure you that, and so.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: But this word.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: I cannot, nor I will not: good Lord

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Well, you shall hear more from me

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: It is charity: besides, I know she is there:
And under visitation I shall see her,
Will ye along?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: By any means.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Be sure then
I be a civil man: I have sport in hand boys,
Shall make mirth for a marriage day.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Away then.

div2.stage: Enter three Physitians with an Vrinall.

sp.speaker: 1 Phis.
sp.l: A Pleurisy, I see it.
I rather hold it
For tremor cords.
Do you mark the Phases?
It is a most pestilent contagious fever,
A surfeit, a plaguey surfeit: he must bleed.

sp.speaker: 1 Phy.
sp.l: By no means.
I say bleed.
I say it is dangerous:
The person being spent so much before hand,
And nature drawn so low, clysters, cool clysters.
Now with your favours, I should think a vomit:
For take away the cause, the effect must follow,
The stomach is foul and furred, the pot is unflamed yet.
No, no, we will rectify that part by mild means,
Nature so sunk, must find no violence.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Will it please ye draw near? the weak gentleman
Grows worse and worse still.
Come, we will attend him.
He shall do well, my friend.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: My masters love sir.
Excellent well I warrant thee, right and straight friend.
There is no doubt in him, none at all, never fear him.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: That he is desperate sick I do believe well,
And that without a speedy cure it kills him,
But that it lies within the help of physic
Now to restore his health, or art to cure him:
Believe it you are cozened: clean beside it.
I would tell ye the true cause too, but it would vex ye,
Nay, run ye mad.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: May all I have restore him?
So dearly and so tenderly I love him,
I do not know the cause why, yea my life too.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Now I perceive ye so well set, I will tell you,

l.foreign: Hei mihi quod nullis amor est medicabilis herbis.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: It was that I only feared: good friend go from me,
I find my heart too full for further conference:
You are assured of this?

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: It will prove too certain,
But bear it nobly sir, youth hath his errors.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I shall do, and I thank ye: pray ye no words on it.
I do not use to talk, Sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Ye are welcome:
Is there no Constancy in earthly things:
No happiness in us, but what must alter,
No life without the heavy load of fortune?
What miseries we are, and to ourselves,
Even then when full content seems to sit by us,
What daily sores, and sorrows?

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: O dear Brother,
The Gentleman if ever you will see him
Alive as I think.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: O he faints, for heaven sake,
For heaven sake sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Go comfort him dear sister.
And one word sweet, with you: then we will go to him.
What think you of this Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: My pity thinks sir,
It is great misfortune, that he should thus perish.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: It is indeed: but Cellide, he must die.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: That were a cruelty, when care may cure him,
Why do you weep so sir, he may recover?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: He may, but with much danger; my sweet Cellide,
You have a powerful tongue.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: To do you service.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I will betray his grief: he loves a gentlewoman,
A friend of yours, whose heart another holds,
He knows it too, yet such a sway blind fancy,
And his not daring to deliver it,
Have won upon him, that they must undo him:
Never so hopeful and so sweet a spirit,
Misfortune fell so foul on.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Sure she is hard hearted,
That can look on, and not relent, and deeply
At such a misery; she is not married?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Not yet.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Nor near it?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: When she please.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: And pray sir,
Does he deserve her truly, that she loves so?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: His love may merit much: his person little,
For there the match lies mangled.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Is he your friend?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: He should be, for he is near me.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Will not he die then?
When the other shall recover?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Ye have posed me.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Methinks he should go near it, if he love her;
If she love him.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: She does, and would do equal:

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: It is a hard task you put me: yet for your sake
I will speak to her: all the art I have:
My best endeavours: all his youth, and person,
His mind more full of beauties: all his hopes,
The memory of such a sad example,
Ill spoken of, and never old: the curses
Of loving maids, and what may be alleged
I will lay before her: what is her name? I am ready

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: But will you deal effectually?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Most truly:
Nay, were it myself, at your entreaty:

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And could ye be so pitiful?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: So dutiful;
Because you urge it sir,

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.l: It may be then
It is yourself.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: It is indeed, I know it.
And now know how ye love me.

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.l: O my dearest,
Let but your goodness judge; your own part is pity:
Set but your eyes on his afflictions:
He is mine, and so becomes your charge: but think
What ruin nature suffers in this young man,
What loss humanity, and noble manhood:
Take to your better judgment my declining,
My age, hung full of impotence, and ills,
My body budding now no more: sere winter
Hath sealed that sap up, at the best and happiest
I can but be your infant, you my nurse,
And how unequal dearest: where his years,
His sweetness, and his ever spring of goodness,
My fortunes growing in him, and myself too,
Which makes him all your old love: misconceive not,
I say not this as weary of my bondage,
Or ready to infringe my faith; bear witness,
Those eyes that I adore still, those lamps that light me
To all the joy I have.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: You have said enough sir,
And more than ever I thought that tongue could utter,
But ye are a man, a false man too.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Dear Cellide.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: And now, to show you that I am a woman
Robbed of her rest, and fooled out of her fondness,
The Gentleman shall live: and if he love me,
Ye shall be both my triumphs; I will to him,
And as you carelessly fling off your fortune,
And now grow weary of my easy winning,
So will I lose the name of Valentine,
From henceforth all his flatteries, and believe it,
Since ye have so so slightly parted with affection,
And that affection you have pawned your faith for;
From this hour, no repentance, vows, nor prayers
Shall pluck me back again: what I shall do,
Yet I will undertake his cure, expect it,
Shall minister no comfort, no content
To either of ye, but hourly more vexations.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Why, let him die then.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: No, so much I have loved
To be commanded by you, that even now,
Even in my hate I will obey your wishes.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What shall I do?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Die like a fool unsorrowed?
A bankrupt fool, that flings away his treasure?
I must begin my cure.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And I my crosses.

div2.stage: Enter Frank sick, Physitians, and a Pothecary.

sp.speaker: 1 Phis.
sp.l: Clap on the Cataplasm.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Good Gentlemen,
Good learned Gentlemen.
And see these broths there,
Ready within this hour, pray keep your arms in,
The air is raw, and ministers much evil.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Pray leave me; I beseech ye leave me gentlemen,
I have no other sickness but your presence,
Convey your Cataplasms to those that need them,
Your Vomits, and your Clysters.
Pray be ruled sir.
Bring in the Lettice cap; you must be shaved sir,
And then how suddenly we will make you sleep.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Till doomsday: what unnecessary nothings
Are these about a wounded mind?
How do ye?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: What questions they propound too: how do you sir?
I am glad to see you well.
A great distemper, it grows hotter still.
Open your mouth I pray sir.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: And can you tell me
How old I am then? there is my hand, pray show me
How many broken shins within this two year.
Who would be thus in fetters, good master Doctor,
And you dear Doctor, and the third sweet Doctor
And precious master Apothecary, I do pray ye
To give me leave to live a little longer,
Ye stand before me like my blacks.
It is dangerous,
For now his fancy turns too.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: By your leave Gentlemen:
And pray ye your leave a while too, I have something
Of secret to impart unto the patient.
With all our hearts.
Aye mary such a Physic
May chance to find the humour: be not long Lady
For we must minister within this half hour.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: You shall not stay for me.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Would you were all rotten
That ye might only intend one another's itches:
Or would the Gentlemen with one consent
Would drink small Beer but seven year, and abolish
That wild fire of the blood, unsatiate wenching
That your two Indies, springs and falls might fail ye
What torments these intruders into bodies.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: How do you worthy Sir?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Bless me, what beams
Flew from these angel eyes: O what a misery
What a most studied torment it is to me now
To be an honest man: dare ye sit by me?

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: Yes; and do more than that too: comfort ye
I see ye have need.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: You are a fair Physician:
You bring no bitterness gilt over, to gull us
No danger in your looks, yet there my death lies.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: I would be sorry sir, my charity
And my good wishes for your health should merit
So stubborn a construction: will it please ye
To taste a little of this Cordial
For this I think must cure ye.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Of which Lady?
Sure she has found my grief? why do you blush so?

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: Do you not understand? of this, this Cordial.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O my afflicted heart: she is gone forever.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: What heaven have ye brought me Lady?

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: Do not wonder:
For it is no impudence, nor want of honour
Makes me do this: but love to save your life sir
Your life, too excellent to lose in wishes,
Love, virtuous love.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: A virtuous blessing crown ye
O goodly sweet, can there be so much charity
So noble a compassion in that heart
That is filled up with another's fair affections?
Can mercy drop from those eyes?
Can miracles be wrought upon a dead man,
When all the power ye have, and perfect object
Lies in another's light, and his deserves it?

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: Do not despair: nor do not think too boldly
I dare abuse my promise, it was your friends
And so fast tyde, I thought no time could ruin:
But so much has your danger, and that spell
The powerful name of friend, prevailed above him
To whom I ever owe obedience,
That here I am, by his command to cure ye,
Nay more forever, by his full resignment,
And willingly I ratify it.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Hold for heaven sake,
Must my friends misery make me a triumph?
Bear I that noble name, to be a Traitor?
O virtuous goodness, keep thyself untainted:
You have no power to yield, nor he to render,
Nor I to take: I am resolved to die first.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Ha; sayst thou so? nay then thou shalt not perish.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: And though I love ye above the light shines on me,
Beyond the wealth of Kingdoms, free content,
Sooner would snatch at such a blessing offered
Than at my pardoned life by the law forfeited,
Yet, yet O noble beauty, yet O Paradise
For you are all the wonder revealed of it,
Yet is a gratitude to be preserved
A worthy gratitude to one most worthy
The name, and nobleness of friends.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: Pray tell me
If I had never known that Gentleman,
Would not you willingly embrace my offer?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Do you make a doubt?

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: And can ye be unwilling
He being old and impotent: his aim too
Levelled at you, for your good? not constrained,
But out of cure, and council? Alas consider
Play but the woman with me, and consider
As he himself does, and I now dare see it
Truly consider sir, what misery.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: For virtues sake take heed.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: What loss of youth,
What everlasting banishment from that
Our years do only covet to arrive at
Equal affections and shot together:
What living name can dead age leave behind him
What art of memory but fruitless doting?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: This cannot be.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: To you unless ye apply it
With more and firmer faith, and so digest it,
I speak but of things possible, not done
Nor like to be, a Posset cures your sickness
And yet I know ye grieve this; and howsoever
The worthiness of Friend may make ye stagger
Which is a fair thing in ye, yet my Patient,
My gentle Patient, I would fain say more
If you would understand.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O cruel Woman.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: Yet sure your sickness is not so forgetful
Nor you so willing to be lost.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Pray stay there:
Methinks you are not fair now; methinks more
That modest, virtue, men delivered of you,
Shows but like shadow to me, thin, and fading.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Excellent Friend.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Ye have no share in goodness:
Ye are belied; you are not Cellide,
The modest, immaculate: who are ye?
For I will know: what devil to do mischief
Unto my virtuous Friend, hath shifted shapes
With that unblemished beauty.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: Do not rave Sir,
Nor let the violence of thoughts distract ye,
You shall enjoy me: I am yours: I pity
By those fair eyes I do.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: O double hearted,
O woman, perfect Woman: what distraction
Was meant to mankind when thou wast made a devil,
What an inviting hell invented? tell me,
And if you yet remember what is goodness,
Tell me by that, and truth, can one so cherished
So sainted in the soul of him, whose service
Is almost turned to superstition,
Whose everyday endeavours and desires
Offer themselves like incense on your altar,
Whose heart holds no intelligence, but holy
And most religious with his love; whose life
(And let it ever be remembered Lady)
Is drawn out only for your ends.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O miracle.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Whose all, and every part of man: pray make me
Like ready Pages wait upon your pleasures;
Whose breath is but your bubble. Can ye, dare ye,
Must ye cast off this man, though he were willing,
Though in a nobleness, to cross my danger
His friendship durst confirm it, without baseness,
Without the stain of honour? shall not people
Say liberally hereafter, there is the Lady
That lost her Father, Friend, herself, her faith too,
To fawn upon a stranger, for aught you know
As faithless as yourself, in love as fruitless?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Take her with all my heart, thou art so honest
That it is most necessary I be undone.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: With all my soul possess her.
Till this minute
I scorned, and hated ye, and came to cozen ye:
Uttered those things might draw a wonder on me,
To make ye mad.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Good heaven, what is this woman?

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: Nor did your danger, but in charity,
Move me a whit: nor you appear unto me
More than a common object; yet, now truly,
Truly, and nobly I do love ye dearly,
And from this hour, ye are the man I honour,
You are the man, the excellence, the honesty,
The only friend, and I am glad your sickness
Fell so most happily at this time on ye,
To make this truth the worlds.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Whether do you drive me?

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: Back to your honesty, make that good ever,
It is like a strong built Castle, seated high,
That draws on all ambitions, still repair it,
Still fortify it: there are thousand foes
Besides the Tyrant Beauty, will assail it:
Look to your Sentinels that watch it hourly,
Your eyes, let them not wander.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Is this serious?
Or does she play still with me?

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: Keep your ears,
The two main ports that may betray ye strongly
From light belief first, then from flattery,
Especially where woman beats the parley:
The body of your strength, your noble heart
From ever yielding to dishonest ends,
Rigged round about with virtue, that no breaches,
No subtle mines may meet ye.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: How like the Sun
Labouring in his Eclipse, dark, and prodigious,
She showed till now? when having won her way,
How full of wonder he breaks out again,
And sheds his virtuous beams: excellent Angel,
For no less can that heavenly mind proclaim thee,
Honour of all thy sex, let it be lawful,
And like a Pilgrim thus I kneel to beg it,
Not with profane lips now, nor burnt affections,
But, reconciled to faith, with holy wishes,
To kiss that virgin hand.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Take your desire sir,
And in a nobler way, for I dare trust ye,
No other fruit my love must ever yield ye,
I fear no more: yet your most constant memory
(So much I am wedded to that worthiness)
Shall ever be my friend, companion, husband.
Farewell, and fairly govern your affections,
Stand, and deceive me not: O noble young man,
I love thee with my soul, but dare not say it:
Once more farewell, and prosper.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Goodness guide thee:
My wonder like to fearful shapes in dreams,
Has wakened me out of my fit of folly,
But not to shake it off: a spell dwells in me,
A hidden charm shot from this beauteous woman,
That fate can never avoid, nor physic find,
And by her counsel strengthened: only this
Is all the help I have, I love fair virtue.
Well, something I must do, to be a friend,
Yet I am poor, and tardy: something for her too,
Though I can never reach her excellence,
Yet but to give an offer at a greatness.

div2.stage: Enter Valentine, Thomas, Hylas, and Sam.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Be not uncivil Tom, and take your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Do you think I am mad? you will give me leave
To try her fairly?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Do your best.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Why there boy,
But where is the sick man?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Where are the gentlewomen
That should attend him, is the patent
Methinks these Women.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Thou thinkst nothing else.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Go to him friend, and comfort him: I will lead ye.
O my best joy, my worthiest friend, pray pardon me,
I am so overjoyed I want expression:
I may live to be thankful: bid your friends welcome.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: How dost thou Frank? how dost thou boy, bear up man:
What, shrink in the sinews for a little sickness?
Deavolo morte.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I am of the mending hand.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: How like a Flute thou speakest: of the mending hand man
God's bores, I am well, speak like a man of worship.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Thou art a mad companion: never staid Tom?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Let Rogues be staid that have no habitation,
A gentleman may wander: sit thee down Frank,
And see what I have brought thee: come discover,
Open the Scene, and let the work appear.
A friend at need you rogue is worth a million.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: What hast thou there, a julep?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: He must not touch it,
It is present death.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Ye are an Ass, a twire-pipe,
A Jeffrey John bo peep, thou minister,
Thou mend a left-handed pack-saddle, out puppy,
My friend Frank, but a very foolish fellow:
Dost thou see that Bottle? view it well.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I do Tom.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: There be as many lives in it, as a Cat carries,
It is everlasting liquor.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Old Sack boy,
Old reverend Sack, which for ought that I can read yet,
Was that Philosophers Stone the wise King Ptolomeus
Did all his wonders by.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I see no harm Tom,
Drink with a moderation.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Drink with sugar,
Which I have ready here, and here a glass boy,
Take me without my tools.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Pray Sir be temperate,
You know your own state best.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Sir, I much thank ye,
And shall be careful: yet a glass or two
So fit I find my body, and that so needful.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Fill it, and leave your fooling: thou sayst true Frank.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Where are these women I say?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: It is most necessary,
Hang up your juleps, and your portugal possets,
Your barley broths, and sorrel sops, they are mangy,
And breed the scratches only: give me Sack:
I wonder where this wench is though: have at thee:

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: So long, and yet no bolting.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Do, I will pledge thee.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Take it off thrice, and then cry heigh like a Huntsman
With a clear heart, and no more fits I warrant thee.
The only Cordial Frank.

sp.speaker: 1 Phis.
sp.l: Are the things ready?
And is the Barber come?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: An hour ago sir.

sp.speaker: 1 Phys.
sp.l: Bring out the oils then.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Now or never gentlemen,
Do me a kindness and deliver me.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: From whom boy?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: From these things, that talk within there,
Physicians, Tom, Physicians, scouring-sticks,
They mean to read upon me.

div2.stage: Enter three Phis. Apoth. and Barber.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Let them enter.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: And be thou confident, we will deliver thee:
For look ye Doctor, say the Devil were sick now,
His horns sawed off and his head bound with a Biggin,
Sick of a calenture, taken by a surfeit
Of stinking souls at his nephews, and Saint Dunstans,
What would you minister upon the sudden?
Your judgment short and sound.

sp.speaker: 1 Ph.
sp.l: A fools head.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: No sir,
It must be a Physicians for three causes,
The first because it is a bald-head likely,
Which will down easily without apple-pap.

sp.speaker: 3 Phis.
sp.l: A main cause.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: So it is, and well considered.
The second, for it is filled with broken Greek sir,
Which will so tumble in his stomach, Doctor,
And work upon the crudities, conceive me
The fears, and the fiddle strings within it,
That those damned souls must disembogue again.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Or meeting with the stygian humour.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Right sir.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Forced with a Cataplasm of crackers.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Ever.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Scour all before him, like a Scavenger.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Satis fecisti domine: my last cause,
My last is, and not least, most learned Doctors,
Because in most Physicians heads (I mean those
That are most excellent, and old withal,
And angry, though a patient say his prayers,
And Paracelsians that do trade with poisons,
We have it by tradition of great writers)
There is a kind of toad-stone bread, whose virtue
The Doctor being dried.

sp.speaker: 1 Phis.
sp.l: We are abused sirs.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: I take it so, or shall be, for say the belly-ache
Caused by an inundation of Pease porridge,
Are we therefore to open the port vein,
Or the port Esquiline?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: A learned question:
Or grant the diaphragm by a rupture,
The sign being then in the head of Capricorn.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Meet with the passion Hupercondriaca,
And so cause a Carnosity in the kidneys.
Must not the brains, being buttered with this humour
Answer me that.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Most excellently argued.

sp.speaker: 2 Phis.
sp.l: The next fit you will have, my most fine scholar,
Bedlam shall find a Salve for: fare ye well sir,
We came to do you good, but these young Doctors
It seems have boared out noses.
Drink hard Gentlemen,
And get unwholesome drabs: it is ten to one then
We shall hear further from ye, your note altered.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: And wilt thou be gone, says one?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: And wilt thou be gone, says the other?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Then take the odd crown
To mend thy old gown.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: And we will be gone all together.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: My learned Tom.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Sir, the young Gentlewomen
Sent me to see what company ye had with ye,
They much desire to visit ye.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Pray ye thank them,
And tell them my most sickness is their absence:
Ye see my company.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Come hither Crab,
What Gentlewomen are these? my Mistress?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: And who else?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Mistress Alice.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: O.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Hark ye sirrah,
No word of my being here, unless she know it.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: I do not think she does.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Take that, and mum, then.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: You have tied my tongue up.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Sit you down good Francis,
And not a word of me till ye hear from me,
And as you find my humour, follow it:
You two come hither, and stand close, unseen boys
And do as I shall tutor ye.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: What, new work?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Prithee no more but help me now.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: I would fain
talk with the gentlewomen

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Talk with the gentlewomen?
Of what forsooth? whose maiden-head the last mask
Suffered impression, or whose clyster wrought best?
Take me as I shall tell thee.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: To what end?
What other end came we along?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Be ruled though.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Your weasel face must needs be ferreting
About the farthing-ale;
Do as I bid ye,
Or by this light.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Come then,

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Stand close and mark me,

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: All this forced foolery will never do it.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.l: I hope we bring ye health sir: how is it with ye?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: You look far better trust me, the fresh colour
Creeps now again into his cheeks.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.l: Your enemy
I see has done his worst. Come, we must have ye
Lusty again, and frolic man; leave thinking

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Indeed it does ye harm sir.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: My best visitants,
I shall be governed by ye.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.l: You shall be well then,
And suddenly, and soundly well.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: This air sir,
Having now seasoned ye, will keep ye ever.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: No, no, I have no hope, nor is it fit friends,
My life has been so lewd, my loose condition,
Which I repent too late, so lamentable,
That anything but curses light upon me,
Exorbitant in all my ways.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: Who is that sir,
Another sick man?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Sure, I know that voice well.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: In all my courses, careless disobedience.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: What a strange fellow is this?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: No counsel friends,
No look before I leapt.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.l: Do you know the voice sir?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Yes, it is a gentleman's that is much afflicted
In his mind: great pity Ladies.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: Now heaven help him.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: He came to me, to ask free pardon of me,
For some things done long since, which his distemper
Made to appear like wrong, but it was not so.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: O that this could be truth.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Persuade yourself.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: To what end gentlemen, when all is perished
Upon a wrack, is there a hope remaining?
The sea, that never knew sorrow, may be pitiful,
My credit is split, and sunk, nor is it possible,
Were my life lengthened out as long as.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I like this well.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Your mind is too mistrustful.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I have a virtuous sister, but I scorned her,
A Mistress too, a noble gentlewoman,
For goodness all out-going.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: Now I know him.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: With these eyes friends, my eyes must never see more.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: This is for your sake Mary: take heed cousin,
A man is not so soon made.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: O my fortune,
But it is just, I be despised and hated.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Despair not, it is not manly: one hours goodness
Strikes off an infinite of ills.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Weep truly
And with compassion Cousin.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: How exactly
This cunning young thief plays his part.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Well Tom,
My Tom again, if this be truth.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: She weeps boy.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: O I shall die.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Now Heaven defend.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Thou hast her.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Come lead me to my Friend to take his farewell,
And then what fortune shall befall me, welcome.
How does it show?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: O rarely well.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Say you so Sir.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: O ye grand Ass.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: And are ye there my Juggler
Away we are abused, Alice.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Fool be with thee.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Where is she.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Gone; she found you out, and finely,
In your own noose she haltered ye: you must be whispering
To know how things showed: not content to fare well
But you must roar out roast meat; till that suspicion
You carried it most neatly, she believed too
And wept most tenderly; had you continued,
Without doubt you had brought her off.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: This was thy Rouging,
For thou wert ever whispering: fie upon thee
Now could I breaks thy head.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: You spoke to me first.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Do not anger me,
For by this hand I will beat the buzzard blind then.
She shall not scape me thus: farewell for this time.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Good night, it is almost bed time: yet no sleep
Must enter these, till I work a wonder.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Thou shalt along too, for I mean to plague thee
For this nights sins, I will never leave walking of thee
Till I have worn thee out.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Your will be done Sir.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: You will not leave me Sam.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Not I.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Away then: I will be your guide now, if my man be trusty
My spiteful Dame, I will pipe ye such a hunt is up
Shall make ye dance a tipvacs: keep close to me.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Never persuade me, I will marry again,
What should I leave my state to, pins and poking sticks
To Farthingales, and frounces, to fore-horses
And an old leather bawdy house behind them
To thee?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: You have a son sir.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Where, what is he?
Who is he like?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Yourself.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Thou liest, thou hast marred him,
Thou, and thy prayer books: I do disclaim him:
Did not I take him singing yesternight
A godly Ballad, to a godly tune too,
And had a Catechism in his pocket Damsel,
One of your dear disciples, I perceive it?
When did he ride abroad since he came over?
What Tavern has he used to? what things done
That shows a man, and mettle? when was my house
At such a shame before, to creep to bed
At ten o'clock, and twelve, for want of company?
No singing, nor no dancing, nor no drinking?
Thou thinkst not of these scandals; when, and where
Has he but showed his sword of late?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Despair not
I do beseech you Sir, nor tempt your weakness,
For if you like it so, I can assure you
He is the same man still.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Would thou wert ashes
On that condition; but believe it gossip
You shall know you have wrong.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: You never Sir,
So will I know my duty: and for heaven sake,
Take but this counsel with ye ere you marry,
You were wont to hear me: take him, and confess him,
Search him to the quick, and if you find him false
Do as please you, a Mothers name I honour.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: He is lost, and spoiled, I am resolved my roof
Shall never harbour him: and for your Minion
I will keep you close enough, lest you break loose,
And do more mischief; get ye in: who waits?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Do you call Sir?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Seek the Boy: and bid him wait
My pleasure in the morning: mark what house
He is in, and what he does: and truly tell me.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: I will not fail sir.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: If ye do, I will hang ye.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Keep you the back door there, and be sure
None of her servants enter, or go out,
If any woman pass, she is lawful prize, boys
Cut off all convoys.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Who shall answer this?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Why, I shall answer it, you fearful wigeon,
I shall appear to the action.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: May we discourse too,
On honourable terms?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: With any Gentlewoman
That shall appear at window: ye may rehearse too
By your commission safely, some sweet parcels
Of Poetry to a Chambermaid.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: May we sing too?
For there is my master-piece.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: By no means, no boys,
I am the man reserved for air, it is my part,
And if she be not rock, my voice shall reach her:
Ye may record a little, or ye may whistle,
As time shall minister, but for main singing,
Pray ye satisfy yourselves: away, be careful.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: But hark ye one word Tom, we may be beaten.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: That is as ye think good yourselves: if you deserve it,
Why it is the easiest thing to compass: beaten?
What bugbears dwell in thy brains? who should beat thee?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: She has men enough.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Art not thou man enough too?
Thou hast flesh enough about thee: if all that mass
Will not maintain a little spirit, hang it,
And dry it too for dogs-meat: get you gone;
I have things of moment in my mind: that door,
Keep it as thou wouldst keep thy wife from a Serving-man
No more I say: away Sam.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: At your will sir.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: I have him here, a rare rogue, good sweet master,
Do something of some favour suddenly,
That we may eat, and live: I am almost starved,
No point manieur, no point devein, no Seignior,
Not by the virtue of my languages,
Nothing at my old masters to be hoped for,
O Seignior du, nothing to line my life with,
But cold Pies with a cudgel, till you help us.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Nothing but famine frights thee: come hither Fiddler,
What Ballads are you seen in best? be short sir.

sp.speaker: Fidler.
sp.l: Under your masterships correction, I can sing
The Duke of Norfolk, or the merry Ballad
Of Diverus and Lazarus, the Rose of England,
In Crete when Dedimus first began,
Jonas his crying out against Coventry.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Excellent,
Rare matters all.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Maudlin the Merchants Daughter,
The Devil, and ye dainty Dames.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Rare still.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: The landing of the Spaniards at Bow,
With the bloody battle at Mile-end.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: All excellent:
No tuning as ye love me; let thy Fiddle
Speak welsh, or anything that is out of all tune,
The viler still the better, like thyself,
For I presume thy voice will make no trees dance.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Nay truly, ye shall have it even as homely.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Keep ye to that key, are they all abed trow?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: I hear no stirring anywhere, no light
In any window, it is a night for the nonce Sir.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Come strike up then: and say the Merchants daughter,
We will bear the burthen: proceed to incision Fiddler.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Who is there? what noise is this? what rogue
At these hours?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: O what is that to you my fool?
O what is that to you,
Pluck in your face you bawling Ass,
Or I will break your brow. hey down, down, a-down.
A new Ballad, a new, a new.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: The twelfth of April, on May day,
My house and goods were burnt away, etcetera.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Why who is this?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: O damsel dear,
Open the door, and it shall appear,
Open the door,
O gentle squire.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: I will see thee hanged first: farewell my dear,
It is master Thomas, there he stands.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.l: It is strange
That nothing can redeem him: rail him hence,
Or sing him out in his own way, anything
To be delivered of him.

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.l: Then have at him:
My man Thomas did me promise.
He would visit me this night.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I am here Love, tell me dear Love,
How I may obtain thy sight.

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.l: Come up to my window love, come, come, come,
Come to my window my dear,
The wind, nor the rain, shall trouble thee again,
But thou shalt be lodged here.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: And art thou strong enough?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Up, up, I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: What dost thou mean to do?

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.l: Good Mistress peace,
I will warrant ye we will cool him: Madge.

sp.speaker: Madge.
sp.l: I am ready.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: The love of Greece, and it tickled him so,
That he devised a way to go.
Now sing the Duke of Northumberland.

sp.speaker: Fidler.
sp.l: And climbing to promotion,
He fell down suddenly.

div2.stage:
Madge with a divels
vizard roring, offers to kisse him, and he fals down.

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.l: Farewell sir.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: What hast thou done? thou hast broke his neck

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.l: Not hurt him,
He pitched upon his legs like a Cat.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: O woman:
O miserable woman, I am spoiled,
My leg, my leg, my leg, o both my legs.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: I told thee what thou hadst done, mischief go with thee.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: O I am lamed forever: O my leg,
Broken in twenty places: O take heed,
Take heed of women, Fiddler: o a Surgeon,
A Surgeon, or I die: o my good people,
No charitable people, all despiteful,
O what a misery am I in: o my leg.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Be patient Sir, be patient: let me bind it.

div2.stage: Enter Samuel, and Hylas with his head broken.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: O do not touch it rogue.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: My head, my head,
O my head is killed.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: You must be courting wenches
Through key-holes, Captain Hylas, come and be comforted,
The skin is scarce broke.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: O my leg.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: How do ye Sir?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: O maimed forever with a fall, he is spoiled too,
I see his brains.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Away with me for Gods sake,
A Surgeon.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Here is a night indeed.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: A Surgeon.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: Go run for help.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: O,

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Run all, and all too little,
O cursed beast that hurt him, run, run, fly,
He will be dead else.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: O.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Good friend go you too.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Who pays me for my Music?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Pox on your Music,
There is twelve pence for ye.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: There is two groats again forsooth,
I never take above, and rest ye merry.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: A grease pot guild your fiddle strings: how do you,
How is my dear?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Why well I thank ye sweet heart,
Shall we walk in, for now there is none to trouble us?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Are ye so crafty sir? I shall meet with ye,
I knew your trick, and I was willing: my Tom,
Mine own Tom, now to satisfy thee, welcome, welcome,
Welcome my best friend to me, all my dearest.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Now ye are my noble Mistress: we lose time sweet.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I think they are all gone.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: All, ye did wisely.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: And you as craftily.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: We are well met Mistress.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Come, let us go in then lovingly: O my Scarf Tom.
I lost it thereabout, find it, and wear it
As your poor Mistress favour.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: I am made now,
I see no venture is in no hand: I have it,
How now? the door locked, and she in before?
Am I so trimmed?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: One parting word sweet Thomas,
Though to save your credit, I discharged your Fiddler,
I must not satisfy your folly too sir,
Ye are subtle, but believe it Fox, I will find ye,
The Surgeons will be here strait, roar again boy,
And break thy legs for shame, thou wilt be sport else,
Good night.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: She says most true, I must not stay: she has bobbed me,
Which if I live, I will recompense, and shortly,
Now for a Ballad to bring me off again.
All young men be warned by me, how you do go a-wooing.
Seek not to climb, for fear ye fall thereby, comes your undoing,

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: He cannot go and take no farewell of me,
Can he be so unkind? he is but retired
Into the Garden or the Orchard: see sirs.
