sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.l: He would not ride there certain, those were planted
Only for walks I take it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Ride? nay then,
Had he a horse out?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: So the Groom delivers
Somewhat before the break of day.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: He is gone,
My best friend is gone Alice; I have lost the noblest,
The truest, and the most man I ever found yet.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: Indeed sir, he deserves all praise.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: All sister,
All, all, and all too little: O that honesty,
That ermine honesty, unspotted ever,
That perfect goodness.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: Sure he will return sir,
He cannot be so harsh.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O never, never,
Never return, thou knowest not where the cause lies.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: He was the worthiest welcome.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: He deserved it.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: Nor wanted, to our knowledge.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I will tell thee,
Within this hour, things that shall startle thee.
He never must return.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Good morrow Seignior.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Good morrow Master Michael.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: My good neighbour,
Methinks you are stirring early since your travel,
You have learned the rule of health sir, where is your mistress?
She keeps her warm I warrant ye, abed yet?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I think she does.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: It is not her hour of waking.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Did you lie with her, Lady?

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: Not tonight sir.
Nor any night this week else.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: When last saw ye her?

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: Late yesternight.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Was she abed then?

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: No Sir,
I left her at her prayers: why do ye ask me?

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: I have been strangely haunted with a dream
All this long night, and after many waking,
The same dream still; methought I met young Cellide
Just at Saint Katherines gate the Nunnery.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Her face slubbered over with tears, and troubles,
Methought she cried unto the Lady Abbess,
For charity receive me holy woman,
A Maid that has forgot the worlds affections,
Into thy virgin order: methought she took her,
Put on a Stole, and sacred robe upon her,
And there I left her.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Dream?

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Good Mistress Alice
Do me the favour (yet to satisfy me)
To step but up, and see.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: I know she is there sir,
And all this but a dream?

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: You know not my dreams,
They are unhappy ones, and often truths,
But this I hope, yet.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: I will satisfy ye.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Neighbours, how does the gentleman?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I know not,
Dream of a Nunnery?

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: How found ye my words
About the nature of his sickness Valentine?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Did she not cry out, it was my folly too
That forced her to this Nunnery? did she not curse me?
For God sake speak: did you not dream of me too,
How basely, poorly, tamely, like a fool,
Tired with his joys?

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Alas poor gentleman,
Ye promised me sir to bear all these crosses.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I bear them till I break again.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: But nobly,
Truly to weigh.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Good neighbours, no more of it,
Ye do but fling flax on my fire: where is she?

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.l: Not yonder Sir, nor has not this night certain
Been in her bed.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: It must be truth she tells ye,
And now I will show ye why I came: this morning
A man of mine being employed about business,
Came early home, who at Saint Katherines Nunnery,
About day peep, told me he met your Mistress,
And as I spoke it in a dream, so troubled
And so received by the Abbess, did he see her?
The wonder made me rise, and hast unto ye
To know the cause.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Farewell, I cannot speak it.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: For heaven sake leave him not.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: I will not Lady.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: Alas, he is much afflicted,

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: We shall know shortly more, apply your own care
At home good Alice, and trust him to my counsel,
Nay, do not weep, all shall be well, despair not.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: At Valentines house so merry?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: As a pie Sir:

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: So gamesome dost thou say?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: I am sure I heard it.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Ballads, and Fiddles too?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: No, but one Fiddle;
But twenty noises.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Did he do devises?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: The best devises sir: here is my fellow Launcelet
He can inform ye all: he was among them,
A mad thing too: I stood but in a corner.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Come Sir, what can you say? is there any hope yet
Your Master may return?

sp.speaker: Laun.
sp.l: He went far else
I will assure your worship on my credit
By the faith of a Traveller, and a Gentleman,
Your son is found again, the son, the Tom.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Is he the old Tom?

sp.speaker: Laun.
sp.l: The old Tom.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Go forward.

sp.speaker: Laun.
sp.l: Next, to consider how he is the old Tom.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Handle me that.

sp.speaker: Laun.
sp.l: I would ye had seen it handled
Last night Sir, as we handled it: cap a pe,
Footer for leers, and learnings; O the noise,
The noise we made.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Good, good.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: The windows clattering
And all the Chambermaids, in such a hubbub,
One with her smock half off, another in haste
With a serving-man's hose upon her head.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Good still.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: A fellow railing out of a loop-hole there
And his mouth stopped with dirt.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: in faith a fine Boy.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Here one of our heads broke.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Excellent good still.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: The gentleman himself young M. Thomas,
Environed with his furious Mermidons
The fiery Fiddler, and myself; now singing,
Now beating at the door, there parleying,
Courting at that window, at the other scaling
And all these several noises to two Trenchers,
Strung with a bottom of brown thread, which showed admirable.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: There eat, and grow again, I am pleased.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Nor here Sir,
Gave we the frolic over: though at length
We quit the Ladies Sconce on composition
But to the silent streets we turned our furies:
A sleeping watchman here we stole the shoes from,
There made a noise, at which he wakes, and follows:
The streets are dirty, takes a queene-hith cold,
Hard cheese, and that chokes him on Monday next:
Windows, and signs we sent to Erebus;
A crew of bawling curs we entertained last,
When having let the pigs loose in out parishes,
O the brave cry we made as high as Algate!
Down comes a Constable, and the Sow his Sister
Most traitorously tramples upon Authority,
There a whole stand of rug gowns routed manly
And the Kings peace put flight: a purblind pig here
Runs me his head into the Admirable Lantern,
Out goes the light, and all turns to confusion:
A Potter rises, to enquire this passion,
A Boar embossed takes sanctuary in his shop,
When twenty dogs rush after, we still cheering
Down goes the pots, and pipkins, down the pudding pans,
The cream bowls cry revenge here, there the candlesticks.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: If this be true, thou little tiny page
This tale that thou tellest me
Then on thy back will I presently hang
A handsome new Livery:
But if this be false, thou little tiny page
As false it well may be
Then with a cudgel of four foot long
I will beat thee from head to toe.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Will the boy come.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: He will Sir.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Time tries all then.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Here he comes now himself Sir.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: To be short Thomas
Because I feel a scruple in my conscience
Concerning the demeanour, and a main one
And therefore like a Father would be satisfied,
Get up to that window there, and presently
Like a most complete Gentleman, come from Tripoly.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Good Lord Sir, how are you misled: what fancies
(Fitter for idle boys, and drunkards, let me speak it,
And with a little wonder I beseech you)
Choke up your noble judgment?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: You Rogue Launcelot,
You lying rascal.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Will ye spoil all again sir.
Why, what a devil do you mean?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Away knave,
Ye keep a company of saucy fellows,
Debauched, and daily drunkards, to devour ye,
Things, whose dull souls, tend to the Cellar only,
Ye are ill advised sir, to commit your credit.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Sirrah, sirrah.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Let me never eat again sir,
Nor feel the blessing of another blue-coat
If this young Gentleman, sweet Master Thomas
Be not as mad as heart can wish: your heart sir,
If yesternights discourse: speak fellow Robin
And if thou speakest less than truth.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: It is strange these varlets.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: By these ten bones Sir, if these eyes, and ears
Can hear and see.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Extreme strange, should thus boldly
Bud in your sight, unto your son.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: O deu guin
Can ye deny, ye beat a Constable
Last night.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: I touch Authority, ye rascal?
I violate the Law?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Good M. Thomas.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Did you not take two Wenches from the Watch too
And put them into pudding lane?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: We mean not
Those civil things you did at M. Valentines,
The Fiddle, and the fa'las.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: O strange impudence?
I do beseech you Sir give no such licence
To knaves and drunkards, to abuse your son thus:
Be wise in time, and turn them off: we live Sir
In a State governed civilly, and soberly
Where each man's actions should confirm the Law,
Not crack, and cancel it.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Lancelot du Lake
Get you upon adventures: cast your coat
And make your exit.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Pur lamour de dieu.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Pur me no purs: but pur at that door, out sirrah,
I will beat ye purblind else, out ye eight languages.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: My blood upon your head.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Purge me them all sir.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: And you too presently.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Even as you please sir.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Bid my maid servant come: and bring my daughter
I will have one shall please me.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: It is most fit Sir.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Bring me the money there: here M. Thomas.
sp.stage: Enter two servants with two bags.
sp.l: I pray sit down, ye are no more my son now,
Good Gentleman be covered.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: At your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: This money I do give ye, because of whilom
You have been thought my son, and by myself too,
And some things done like me: ye are now another
There is two hundred pound, a civil sum
For a young civil man: much land and Lordship
Will as I take it now, but prove temptation
To dread ye from your settled, and sweet carriage.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: You say right Sir.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Nay I beseech ye cover.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: At your dispose: and I beseech ye too Sir,
For the word civil, and more settled course
It may but put to use, that on the interest
Like a poor Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: It shall, to my use,
To mine again: do you see sir: good fine gentleman,
I give no brooding money for a Scrivener,
Mine is for present traffic, and so I will use it.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: So much for that then.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: For the main cause Monsieur,
I sent to treat with you about, behold it;
Behold that piece of story work, and view it.
I want a right heir to inherit me,
Not my estate alone, but my conditions,
From which you are revolted, therefore dead,
And I will break my back, but I will get one.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Will you choose there sir?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: There, among those Damsels,
In mine own tribe: I know their qualities
Which cannot fail to please me: for their beauties
A matter of a three farthings, makes all perfect,
A little beer, and beef broth: they are sound too.
Stand all abreast: now gentle M. Thomas
Before I choose, you having lived long with me,
And happily sometimes with some of these too,
Which fault I never frowned upon; pray show me
(For fear we confound our Genealogies)
Which have you laid aboard? speak your mind freely,
Have you had copulation with that Damsel?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: I have.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Stand you aside then: how with her sir?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: How, is not seemly here to say.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Here is fine sport.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Retire you too: speak forward M. Thomas.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: I will: and to the purpose; even with all Sir.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: With all? that is somewhat large.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: And yet you like it.
Was ever sin so glorious?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: With all Thomas.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: All surely sir.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: A sign thou art mine own yet,
In again all: and to your several functions.
What say you to young Luce, my neighbours Daughter,
She was too young I take it, when you travelled;
Some twelve years old?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Her will was fifteen Sir.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: A pretty answer, to cut off long discourse,
For I have many yet to ask ye of,
Where I can choose, and nobly, hold up your finger
When ye are right: what say ye to Valeria
Whose husband lies a-dying now? why two,
And in that form?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Her husband is recovered.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: A witty moral: have at ye once more Thomas,
The Sisters of St. Albones, all five; that boy,
That is mine own boy.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Now out upon thee Monster.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Still hoping of your pardon.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: There needs none man:
A straw on pardon: prithee need no pardon:
I will ask no more, nor think no more of marriage,
For on my conscience I shall be thy Cuckold:
There is some good yet left in him: bear yourself well,
You may recover me, there is twenty pound sir,
I see some sparkles which may flame again,
You may eat with me when you please, you know me.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Why do you lie so damnably, so foolishly?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Dost thou long to have thy head broke? hold thy peace
And do as I would have thee, or by this hand
I will kill thy Parrot, hang up thy small hand,
And drink away thy dowry to a penny.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Was ever such a wild Ass?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Prithee be quiet.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: And dost thou think men will not beat thee monstrously
For abusing their wives and children?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: And dost thou think
Men's wives and children can be abused too much?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I wonder at thee.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Nay, thou shalt adjure me
Before I have done.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: How stand ye with your mistress?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: I shall stand nearer
Ere I be twelve hours older: there is my business,
She is monstrous subtle Doll.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.l: The devil I think
Cannot out-subtle thee.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: If he play fair play,
Come, you must help me presently.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I discard ye.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Thou shalt not sleep nor eat.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I will no hand with ye;
No bawd to your abuses.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: By this light Doll,
Nothing but in the way of honesty.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Thou never knewest that road: I hear your vigils.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Sweet honey Doll, if I do not marry her,
Honestly marry her, if I mean not honourably,
Come, thou shalt help me, take heed how you vex me,
I will help thee to a husband too, a fine gentleman,
I know thou art mad, a tall young man, a brown man,
I swear he has his maidenhead, a rich man.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: You may come in to dinner, and I will answer ye.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Nay I will go with thee Doll: four hundred a year wench.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Good Sir go back again, and take my counsel,
Sores are not cured by sorrows, nor time broke from us,
Pulled back again by sighs.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What should I do friend?

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Do that that may redeem ye, go back quickly,
Sebastians daughter can prevail much with her;
The Abbess is her Aunt too.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: But my friend then
Whose love and loss is equal tied.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Content ye,
That shall be my task if he be alive,
Or where my travel and my care may reach him,
I will bring him back again.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Say he come back
To piece his poor friends life out? and my mistress
Be vowed forever a recluse?

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: So suddenly
She cannot, haste ye therefore instantly away sir,
To put that Daughter by; first as to a Father,
Then as a friend she was committed to ye,
And all the care she now has: by which privilege
She cannot do her this violence,
But you may break it, and the law allows ye.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O but I forced her to it.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Leave disputing
Against yourself, if you will needs be miserable
Spite of her goodness, and your friends persuasions,
Think on, and thrive thereafter.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I will home then.
And follow your advise, and good, good Michael.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: No more, I know your soul is divided, Valentine,
Cure but that part at home with speedy marriage
Ere my return, for then those thoughts that vexed her,
While there ran any stream for loose affections,
Will be stopped up, and chaste-eyed honour guide her
Away, and hope the best still: I will work for ye,
And pray too heartily, away, no more words.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: I care not for my broken head,
But that it should be his plot, and a wench too,
A lousy, lazy wench prepared to do it.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Thou hadst as good be quiet, for on my conscience
He will put another on thee else.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: I am resolved
To call him to account, was it not manifest
He meant a mischief to me, and laughed at me,
When he lay roaring out, his leg was broken,
And no such matter: had he broke his neck,
Indeed it would never have grieved me; gallows gall him.
Why should he choose out me?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Thou art ever ready
To thrust thyself into these she occasions,
And he as full of knavery to accept it.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Well, if I live, I will have a new trick for him.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: That will not be amiss, but to fight with him
Is to no purpose: besides, he is truly valiant,
And a most deadly hand; thou never foughtest yet,
Nor on my conscience hast no faith in fighting.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: No, no, I will not fight.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Besides the quarrel,
Which has a woman in it to make it scurvy,
Who would lie stinking in a Surgeons hands
A month or two this weather? for believe it,
He never hurts under a quarters healing.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: No, upon better thought, I will not fight Sam,
But watch my time

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: To pay him with a project:
Watch him too, I would wish ye: prithee tell me,
Dost thou affect these women still?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Yes faith, Sam,
I love them even as well as ever I did,
Nay, if my brains were beaten out, I must to them.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Dost thou love any woman?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Any woman
Of what degree or calling.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Of any age too?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Of any age, from fourscore to fourteen boy,
Of any fashion.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: And defect too?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Right,
For those I love to lead me to repentance;
A woman with no nose, after my surquedry,
Shows like King Philips Moral, Memento mori;
And she that has a wooden leg, demonstrates
Like Hypocrites, we halt before the gallows;
An old one with one tooth, seems to say to us,
Sweets meats have sour sauce; she that is full of aches,
Crumb not your Bread before you taste your porridge,
And many morals we may find.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: It is well sir,
Ye make so worthy uses; but quid igitur,
What shall we now determine?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Let us consider
An hour or two how I may fit this fellow.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Let us find him first, he will quickly give occasion,
But take heed to yourself, and say I warned ye;
He has a plaguey pate.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: That at my danger.

div2.stage: Enter Saylors singing to them, Michael and Francis.

sp.speaker: Sayl.
sp.l: Aboard, aboard, the wind stands fair.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: These call for Passengers, I will stay and see
What men they take aboard.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: A Boat, a boat, a boat.

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.l: Away then.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Whither are ye bound friends?

sp.speaker: Sayl.
sp.l: Down to the Straits.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Ha, it is not much unlike him.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: May I have passage for my money?

sp.speaker: Sayl.
sp.l: And welcome too.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: It is he, I know it is he now.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Then merrily aboard, and noble friend
Heavens goodness keep thee ever, and all virtue
Dwell in thy bosom Cellide, my last tears
I leave behind me thus, a sacrifice,
For I dare stay no longer to betray ye.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Be not so quick sir; Sailors I here charge ye
By virtue of this warrant, as you will answer it,
For both your ship and Merchant I know perfectly:
Lay hold upon this fellow.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Fellow?

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Aye sir.

sp.speaker: Sayl.
sp.l: No hand to sword sir, we shall master ye,
Fetch out the manacles.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I do obey ye:
But I beseech ye sir, inform me truly
How I am guilty.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Ye have robbed a gentleman,
One that ye are bound to for your life and being:
Money and horse unjustly ye took from him,
And something of more note, but for ye are a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: It shall be so, and here I will end all miseries,
Since friendship is so cruel, I confess it,
And which is more, a hundred of these robberies:
This Ring I stole too from him: and this jewel
The first and last of all my wealth: forgive me
My innocence and truth, for saying I stole them,
And may they prove of value but to recompense
The thousand part of his love, and bread I have eaten.
Pray see them rendered noble sir, and so
I yield me to your power.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Guard him to the water,
I charge you Sailors, there I will receive him,
And back convey him to a Justice.

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.l: Come sir,
Look to your neck, you are like to sail in the air now.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Come quickly, quickly, quickly, paint me handsomely
Take heed my nose be not in grain too,
Come Doll, Doll, disen me.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: If you should play now
Your devils parts again.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Yea and nay Dorothy.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: If ye do anything, but that ye have sworn to,
Which only is access.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: As I am a Gentleman:
Out with this hair Doll, handsomely.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: You have your breeches?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: I prithee away, thou knowest I am monstrous ticklish,
What dost thou think I love to blast my buttocks?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I will plague ye for this roguery: for I know well
What ye intend sir.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: On with my Muffler.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Ye are a sweet Lady: come, let us see you curtsy:
What, broke in the bum, hold up your head.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Plague on it,
I shall bepiss my breeches if I cower thus,
Come, am I ready.

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.l: At all points as like sir,
As if you were my Mistress.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Who goes with ye.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: None but my fortune, and myself.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Bless ye
Now run for thy life, and get before him,
Take the byway, and tell my Cousin Marie
In what shape he intends to come to cozen her
I will follow at thy heels myself: fly wench

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.l: I will do it.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: My Father has met him; this goes excellent
And I will away in time: look to your skin, Thomas.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: What, are you grown so corn fed, goody Gillian.
You will not know your Father: what vagaries
Have you in hand, what outleaps, dirty heels,
That at these hours of night ye must be gadding,
And through the Orchard take your private passage;
What, is the breeze in your breech, or has your brother
Appointed you an hour of meditation.
How to demean himself, get ye to bed, drab
Or I will so crab your shoulders: ye demure slut
Ye civil dish of sliced beef get ye in.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: I will not, that I will not.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Is it even so, Dame
Have at ye with a night spell then.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Pray hold sir.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: St. Geoge, St. Geoge, our Ladies knight
He walks by day, so does he by night,
And when he had her found,
He her beat, and her bound,
Until to him her troth she plight,
She would not stir from him that night.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Then have at ye with a counter-spell,
From Elves, Hobs, and Fairies, that trouble our Dairies,
From Fire-drakes and fiends, and such as the devil sends,
Defend us heaven.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Bless my Master: look up sir, I beseech ye,
Up with your eyes to heaven.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Up with your nose sir,
I do not bleed, it was a sound knock she gave me,
A plaguey mankind girl, how my brains totters?
Well, go thy ways, thou hast got one thousand pound more
With this dog trick,
Mine wone true spirit in her too,

sp.speaker: Laun.
sp.l: In her, alas sir,
Alas poor gentlewoman, she a hand so heavy
To knock ye like a Calf down, or so brave a courage
To beat her father? if you could believe sir.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Who wouldst thou make me believe it was, the devil?

sp.speaker: Laun.
sp.l: One that spits fire as fast as he sometimes sir,
And changes shapes as often: your son Thomas:
Never wonder, if it be not he, straight hang me.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: He? if it be so,
I will put thee in my Will, and there is an end on it.

sp.speaker: Laun.
sp.l: I saw his legs, has Boots on like a Player,
Under his wenches clothes: it is he, it is Thomas
In his own sisters clothes, sir, and I can waste him.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: No more words then, we will watch him: thou wilt not believe Lance,
How heartily glad I am.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: May ye be gladder,
But not this way sir.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: No more words, but watch him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: When comes he?

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.l: Presently.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Then get you up Doll,
Away, I will strait come to you: is all ready?

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.l: All.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Let the light stand far enough.

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.l: It is placed so.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Stay you to entertain him to his chamber,
But keep close, Wench, he flies at all.

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.l: I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You need no more instruction?

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.l: I am perfect.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: More stops yet? sure the fiend is my ghostly father,
Old Valentine: what wind is in his poop?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Lady,
You are met most happily; O gentle Doll,
You must now do me an especial favour.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: What is it, master Valentine? I am sorely troubled
With a salt rheum fallen in my gums.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I will tell ye,
And let it move you equally: my blessed Mistress
Upon a slight occasion taking anger,
Took also (to undo me) your Aunts Nunnery,
From whence by my persuasion to redeem her,
Will be impossible: nor have I liberty
To come, and visit her: my good, good Dorothy,
You are most powerful with her, and your Aunt too,
And have access at all hours liberally,
Speak now, or never for me.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: In a Nunnery?
That course must not be suffered Master Valentine,
Her mother never knew it; rare sport for me:
Sport upon sport, by the break of day I will meet ye,
And fear not man, we will have her out I warrant ye,
I cannot stay now.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You will not break?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: By no means.
Good night.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Good night kind Mistress Doll.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: This thrives well,
Everyone takes me for my sister, excellent:
This Nunnery is fall so pat too, to my figure,
Where there be handsome wenches, and they shall know it
If once I creep in, ere they get me out again:
Stay, here is the house and one of her Maids.

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.l: Who is there?
O Mistress Dorothy you are a stranger.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Still Mistress Dorothy? this gear will cotton.

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.l: Will you walk in forsooth?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Where is your Mistress?

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.l: Not very well; she is gone to bed, I am glad
You are come so fit to comfort her.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Yes, I will comfort her.

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.l: Pray make not much noise, for she is sure asleep,
You know your side, creep softly in, your company
Will warm her well.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I warrant thee I will warm her.

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.l: Your brother has been here, the strangest fellow.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: A very rogue, a rank rogue.

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.l: I will conduct ye
Even to her chamber door, and there commit ye.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Come sir, for this night I shall entertain ye,
And like a gentleman, however your fortune
Hath cast ye on the worst part.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: How you please sir,
I am resolved, nor can a joy or misery
Much move me now.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: I am angry with myself now
For putting this forced way upon his patience,
Yet any other course had been too slender:
Yet what to think I know not, for most liberally
He hath confessed strange wrongs, which if they prove so,
However the others long love may forget all,
Yet it was most fit he should come back, and this way.
Drink that: and now to my care leave your prisoner,
I will be his guard for this night.

sp.speaker: Officers.
sp.l: Good night to your worship.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Good night my honest friends: Come sir, I hope
There shall be no such cause of such a sadness
As you put on.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Faith sir, my rest is up,
And what I now pull, shall no more afflict me
Than if I played at span-counter, nor is my face
The map of anything I seem to suffer,
Lighter affections seldom dwell in me sir.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: A constant gentleman; would I had taken
A fever when I took this harsh way to disturb him,
Come walk with me sir, ere tomorrow night
I doubt not but to see all this blown over.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: I have dogged his Sister, sure it was she,
And I hope she will come back again this night too:

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: I have lost of purpose: now if I can
With all the art I have, as she comes back,
But win a parley for my broken pate,
Off goes her maiden-head, and there is vindicta.
They stir about the house, I will stand at distance.

div2.stage: Enter Mary and Dorothy, and then Thomas & Maid.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.l: Is he come in?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Speak softly,
He is, and there he goes.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Good night, good night wench.

div2.stage: a Bed discovered with a black more in it.

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.l: As softly as you can.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I will play the mouse Nan,
How close the little thief lies!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: How he itches?

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.l: What would you give now to be there, and I
At home, Mall?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Peace for shame.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: In what a figure
The little fool has pulled itself together:
Anon you will lie straighter;
Ha, there is rare circumstance
Belongs to such a treatise: do ye tumble,
I will tumble with ye straight wench: she sleeps soundly,
Full little thinkst thou of thy joy that is coming,
The sweet, sweet joy, full little of the kisses,
But those unthought of things come ever happiest.
How soft the Rogue feels? O ye little villain,
Ye delicate coy thief, how I shall thrum ye?
Your fie away, good servant, as you are a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Prithee leave laughing.
Out upon ye, Thomas
What do ye mean to do? I will call the house up.
O god, I am sure ye will not, shall not serve ye,
For up ye go now, if ye were my Father.

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.l: Your courage will be cold anon.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: If it do hang for
Yet I will be quartered here first.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: O fierce villain.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: What would he do indeed, Doll?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: You had best try him.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I will kiss thee ere I come to bed: sweet Mary.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Prithee leave laughing.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: O, for gentle Nicholas.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: And view that stormy face, that has so thundered me,
A coldness crept over it now; by your leave, candle,
And next door by yours too, so, a pretty, pretty,
Shall I now look upon ye? by this light it moves me.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Much good may it do you sir.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Holy saints, defend me,
The devil, devil, devil, O the devil.

sp.speaker: Ma., Dor.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, ha, the devil, O the devil.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: I am abused most damnedly: most beastly,
Yet if it be a she devil; But the house is up,
And here is no staying longer in this Cassock.
Woman, I here disclaim thee; and in vengeance
I will marry with that devil, but I will vex thee.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Byrlady, but you shall not sir, I will watch ye.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Plague on your spanish leather hide: I will waken ye:
Devil good night: good night, good devil.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: O?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Roar again, devil, roar again.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: O, O, sir.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Open the doors before him; let him vanish:
Now, let him come again, I will use him kinder.
How now Wench?

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Pray lie here yourself, next Mistress
And entertain your sweet heart.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: What said he to thee.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: I had a soft bed: and I slept out all,
But his kind farewell: ye may bake me now,
For on my conscience, he has made me venison.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Alas poor Kate: I will give thee a new Petticoat.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: And I a Waistcoat, Wench.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Draw in the bed Maids,
And see it made again; put fresh sheets on too,
For Doll and I; come Wench, let us laugh an hour now,
Tomorrow, early, will we see young Cellide
They say she has taken Sanctuary: love, and they
Are thick sown, but come up so full of thistles.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: They must needs Mall: for it is a pricking age grown
Prithee to bed, for I am monstrous sleepy.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: A match, but art not thou thy Brother?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I would I were Wench,
You should hear further.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Come, no more of that Doll.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: I Heard the doors clap: now, if it be thy will, wench
By the mass she comes: you are surely melt fair gentlewoman,
I take it, Mistress Doll, Sebastians Daughter.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I take right sir: Hylas, are you ferreting
I will fit you with a pennyworth presently.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: How dare you walk so late so sweet: so weak guarded?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Faith sir, I do no harm, nor none I look for,
Yet I am glad, I have met so good a gentleman,
Against all chances: for though I never knew ye
Yet I have heard much good spoke of ye.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Hark ye.
What if a man should kiss ye?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: That is no harm sir,
Pray God he scapes my beard, there lies the mischief.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Her lips are monstrous rugged, but that surely
Is but the sharpness of the weather: hark ye once more,
And in your ear, sweet Mistress, for ye are so,
And ever shall be from this hour: I have vowed it.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Why, that is my daughter, rogue, dost thou not see her
Kissing that fellow there, there in that corner?

sp.speaker: Laun.
sp.l: Kissing?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Now, now, now they agree on the match too.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Nay then ye love me not.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: By this white hand Doll.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I must confess, I have long desired your sight sir.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Why there is the Boots still sir.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Hang Boots sir,
Why they will wear breeches too.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Dishonest me
Not for the world.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Why now they kiss again, there
I knew it was she, and that her crafty stealing
Out the back way must needs have such a meaning.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: I am at my small wits end.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: If ye mean honourably.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Did she never beat ye before sir?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Why dost thou follow me?
Thou rascal slave hast thou not twice abused me?
Hast thou not spoiled the boy? by thine own covenant,
Wouldst thou not now be hanged?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: I think I would sir,
But you are so impatient: does not this show sir,
(I do beseech ye speak, and speak with judgment,
And let the case be equally considered)
Far braver in your daughter? in a son now
It is nothing, of no mark; every man does it,
But to beget a daughter, a man maiden,
That reaches at these high exploits, is admirable:
Nay, she goes far beyond him; for when durst he,
But when he was drunk, do anything to speak of?
This is Sebastian truly.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Thou sayst right Lance,
And there is my hand once more.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Not without Marriage.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Didst thou hear that?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: I think she spoke of marriage.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: And he shall marry her, for it seems she likes him,
And their first boy shall be my heir.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Aye marry
Now ye go right to work.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Fie, fie sir,
Now I have promised ye this night to marry,
Would ye be so intemperate? are ye a gentleman?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: I have no maw to marriage, yet this rascal
Tempts me extremely: will ye marry presently?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Get you afore, and stay me at the Chapel,
Close by the Nunnery, there you shall find a night Priest,
Little sir Hugh, and he can say the Matrimony
Over without book, for we must have no company
Nor light, for fear my father know, which must not yet be;
And then tomorrow night.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Nothing tonight, sweet?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: No, not a bit, I am sent of business
About my dowry, sweet, do not spoil all now,
It is of much haste: I can scarce stay the marriage,
Now if you love me, get you gone.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: You will follow?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Within this hour, my sweet chick.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Kiss.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: A rope kiss ye,
Come, come, I stand on thorns.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Methinks her mouth still
Is monstrous rough, but they have ways to mend it,
Farewell.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Farewell, I will fit ye with a wife, sir.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Come, follow close, I will see the end she aims at,
And if he be a handsome fellow, Launcelot,
Fiat, it is done, and all my state is settled.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: Come to your Matins Maids; these early hours
My gentle daughter, will disturb a while,
Your fair eyes, nurtured in ease.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: No virtuous Mother,
It is for my holy health, to purchase which,
They shall forget the child of ease, soft slumbers.
O my afflicted heart, how thou art tortured,
And Love, how like a Tyrant thou reignest in me,
Commanding and forbidding at one instant:
Why came I hither that desire to have
Only all liberty, to make me happy?
Why didst thou bring that young man home, O Valentine,
That virtuous youth, why didst thou speak his goodness
In such a phrase, as if all tongues, all praises
Were made for him? O fond and ignorant,
Why didst thou foster my affection
Till it grew up to know no other father,
And then betray it?

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: Can ye sing?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Yes, Mother,
My sorrows only.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: Be gone, and to the Quire then.

div2.stage: Enter Michael and Servant, and Francis.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Hast thou enquired him out?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: He is not at home sir,
His sister thinks he is gone to the Nunnery.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Most likely; I will away, an hour hence sirrah,
Come you along with this young gentleman,
Do him all service, and fair office.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Where hast thou been man?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Is there never a shop open?
I will give thee a pair of gloves Sam.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: What dost thou think?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Thou art not married?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: By the mass but I am, all to be married,
I am in the order now, Sam.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: To whom prithee?
I thought there was some such trick in it, you stole from me,
But who, for heaven sake?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Even the sweetest woman,
The rarest woman Samuel, and the lustiest,
But wondrous honest, honest as the ice boy,
Not a bit before hand, for my life, sirrah,
And of a lusty kindred.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: But who, Hylas?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: The young gentleman and I are like to be friends again,
The fates will have it so.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Who, Monsieur Thomas?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: All wrongs forgot.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: O now I smell ye, Hylas.
Does he know of it?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: No, there is the trick I owe him.
It is done boy, we are fast in faith, my youth now
Shall know I am aforehand, for his qualities.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Is there no trick in it?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: None, but up and ride boy:
I have made her no jointure neither, there I have paid him.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: She is a brave wench.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: She shall be, as I will use her,
And if she anger me, all his abuses
I will clap upon her Cassock.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Take heed, Hylas.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: It is past that Sam, come, I must meet her presently,
And now shalt see me, a most glorious husband.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: In troth sir, you never spoke to me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Can ye forget me?
Did not you promise all your help and cunning
In my behalf, but for one hour to see her,
Did you not swear it? by this hand, no strictness
Nor rule this house holds, shall by me be broken.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I saw ye not these two days.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Do not wrong me,
I met ye, by my life, just as you entered
This gentle Ladies Lodge last night, thus suited
About eleven o'clock.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: It is true, I was there,
But that I saw or spoke to you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I have found it,
Your brother Thomas, Doll.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Pray sir be satisfied,
And wherein I can do you good, command me.
What a mad fool is this? stay here a while sir,
Whilst we walk in, and make your peace.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I thank ye.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: Why, what is the matter there among these Maids?
Now benedicite, have ye got the breeze there?
Give me my holy sprinkle.

sp.speaker: 1 Nun.
sp.l: O Madam, there is a strange thing like a gentlewoman,
Like Mistress Dorothy, I think the fiend
Crept into the Nunnery we know not which way,
Plays revel rout among us.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: Give me my holy water pot.

sp.speaker: 1 Nun.
sp.l: Here Madam.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: Spirit of earth or air, I do conjure thee,
Of water or of fire.

sp.speaker: 1 Nun.
sp.l: Hark Madam, hark.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: Be thou Ghost that cannot rest: or a shadow of the blessed,
Be thou black, or white, or green, be thou heard, or to be seen.

sp.speaker: 2 Nun.
sp.l: It comes, it comes.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: What are ye? speak, speak gently,
And next, what would ye with me?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Anything you will let me.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: You are no woman certain.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Nor you no Nun, nor shall not be.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: What make ye here?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: I am a holy Fryer.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: Is this the Spirit?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Nothing but spirit Aunt.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: Now out upon thee.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Peace, or I will conjure too Aunt.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: Why come you thus?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: That is all one, here is my purpose:
Out with this Nun, she is too handsome for ye,
I will tell thee (Aunt) and I speak it with tears to thee,
If thou keptest her here, as yet I hope thou art wiser,
Mark but the mischief follows.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: She is a Votaress.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Let her be what she will, she will undo thee,
Let her but one hour out, as I direct ye,
Or have among your Nuns again.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.l: You have no project
But fair and honest?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: As thine eyes, sweet Abbess.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.l: I will be ruled then.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Thus then and persuade her,
But do not juggle with me, if ye do Aunt.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.l: I must be there myself.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Away and fit her.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.l: Come daughter, you must now be ruled, or never.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: I must obey your will.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: That is my good daughter.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: What a coil has this Fellow kept in the Nunnery
Sure he has run the Abbess out of her wits.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.l: Out of the Nunnery I think, for we can neither see her,
Nor the young Cellide.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Pray heavens he be not teasing.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Nay you may thank yourself, it was your own structures.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Why there is the gentlewoman,

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Mass it is she indeed
How smart the pretty thief looks? morrow Mistress.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Good morrow to you sir.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: How strange she bears it?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Maids must do so, at first.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Would ye aught with us, gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Yes marry would I
A little with your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Your will sir.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Doll, I would have ye presently prepare yourself
And those things you would have with you,
For my house is ready.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: How sir?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: And this night not to fail, you must come to me,
My Friends will all be there too: For Trunks, and those things
And household stuff, and clothes you would have carried
Tomorrow, or the next day, I will take order:
Only, what money you have, bring away with ye,
And Jewels.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Jewels sir?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Aye, for adornment
There is a bed up, to play the game in, Dorothy:
And now come kiss me heartily.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Who are you?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: This Lady shall be welcome too.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: To what sir?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Your neighbour can resolve ye.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: The man is foolish
Sir, you look soberly: who is this fellow,
And where is his business?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: By Heaven, thou art abused still.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: It may be so: Come, ye may speak now boldly
There is none but friends, Wench.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Came ye out of Bedlam?
Alas, it is ill sir, that ye suffer him
To walk in the open air thus: it will undo him.
A pretty handsome gentleman: great pity.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Let me not live more if thou beest not cozens,

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Are not you my Wife? did not I marry you last night
At Saint Michael's Chapel?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Did not I say he was mad?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Are not you Mistress Dorothy, Thomas sister?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: There he speaks sense, but I will assure ye gentleman,
I think no Wife of yours: at what hour was it?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: 'sprecious; you will make me mad; did not the Priest
Sir Hugh that you appointed, about twelve o'clock
Tie our hands fast? did not you swear you loved me?
Did not I court ye, coming from this gentlewomans?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Good Sir, go sleep: for if I credit have
She was in my arms, then, abed.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: I told ye.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Be not so confident.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: By the mass, she must sir.
For I will no husband here, before I know him:
And so good morrow to ye: Come, let us go seek them.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: I told ye what ye had done.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Is the devil stirring?
Well, go with me; for now I will be married.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: I Have brought him back again.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You have done a friendship
Worthy the love you bear me.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Would he had so too.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O he is a worthy young man.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: When all is tried
I fear you will change your faith: bring in the gentleman.

div2.stage:
Enter Francis, and servant, and Abbesse, and
Cellide, severally.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: My happy Mistress too: now Fortune help me,
And all you stars, that govern chaste desires
Shine fair, and lovely.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.l: But one hour, dear Daughter,
To hear your Guardian, what he can deliver
In Loves defence, and his: and then your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: Though much unwilling, you have made me yield,
More for his sake I see: how full of sorrow
Sweet catching sorrow, he appears? O love,
That thou but knewest to heal, as well as hurt us.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Be ruled by me: I see her eye fast on him:
And what ye heard, believe, for it is so certain
He neither dared, nor must oppose my evidence;
And be you wise, young Lady, and believe too.
This man you love, Sir?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: As I love my soul, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: This man you put into a free possession
Of what his wants could ask: or yourself render?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And shall do still.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Nothing was bard his liberty
But this fair Maid; that friendship first was broken,
And you, and she abused; next, (to my sorrow
So fair a form should hide so dark intentions,)
He hath himselfe confessed (my purpose being
Only to stop his Journey, by that policy
Of laying felony to his charge, to fright the Sailors)
Divers abuses, done, thefts often practised,
Moneys, and Jewels too, and those no trifles.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: O where have I bestrewed my faith: in neither:
Let us in forever now, there is virtue.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Nay do not wonder at it, he shall say it.
Are ye not guilty thus?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Yes: O my Fortune.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: To give a proof: I speak not enviously
Look here: do you know these Jewels.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: In, good Mother.

div2.stage:
Enter Thomas, Dorothy, and Mary: then Sebastian
and Launcelot.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: These Jewels, I have known.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: You have made brave sport.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I will make more, if I live Wench
Nay do not look on me; I care not for ye.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Do you see now plain? that is Mistress Dorothy,
And that is his Mistress.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Peace, let my joy work easily,
Ha, boy: art there my boy: mine own boy, Tom, boy,
Home Lance, and strike a fresh piece, of wine, the town is ours.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Sure, I have known these Jewels.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: They are they, certain.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Good heaven, that they were.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: I will pawn my life on it,
And this is he; Come hither Mistress Dorothy,
And Mistress Mary: who does that face look like:
And view my brother well?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: In truth like him.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Upon my troth exceeding like.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Beshrew me,
But much: and main resemblance, both of face
And lineaments of body: now heaven grant it.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: My brother is full of passion, I will speak to him.
Now, as you are a Gentleman, resolve me,
Where did you get these jewels?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Now I will tell ye,
Because blind fortune yet may make me happy,
Of whom I had them, I have never heard yet,
But from my infancy, upon this arm
I ever wore them.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: It is Francisco brother,
By heaven I tied them on: a little more sir,
A little, little more, what parents have ye?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: None,
That I know yet: the more my stubborn fortune,
But as I heard a Merchant say that bred me,
Who, to my more affliction, died a poor man,
When I reached eighteen years.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: What said that Merchant?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: He said, an infant, in the Genoway Galleys,
But from what place he never could direct me.
I was taken in a sea-fight, and from a Mariner,
Out of his manly pity he redeemed me.
He told me of a Nurse that waited on me,
But she, poor soul, he said was killed.
A Letter too I had enclosed within me.
To one Castructio a Venetian Merchant,
To bring me up: the man, when years allowed me,
And want of friends compelled, I sought, but found him
Long dead before, and all my hopes gone with him.
The wars was my retreat then, and my travel
In which I found this gentleman's free bounty,
For which Heaven recompensed him: now ye have all.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And all the worldly bliss that heaven can send me,
And all my prayers and thanks.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: Down on your knees sir,
For now you have fond a father, and that father
That will not venture ye again in Galleys.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: It is true, believe her sir, and we all joy with ye.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: My best friend still: my dearest: now heaven bless thee.
And make me worthy of this benefit.
Now my best Mistress.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Now sir, I come to ye.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: No, no, let us in wench.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Not for the world, now, Mother,
And thus sir, all my service I pay to you,
And all my love to him.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And may it prosper,
Take her Francisco: now no more young Callidon,
And love her dearly, for thy father does so.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: May all hate seek me else, and thus I seal it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Nothing but mirth now, friends.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Nay, I will find him.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: What do all these here?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: You are a trusty Husband,
And a hot lover too.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Nay then, good morrow,
Now I perceive the knavery.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: I still told ye.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Stay, or I will make ye stay: come hither sister,

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Why how now Mistress Thomas?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Peace a little,
Thou wouldst fain have a wife?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Not I, by no means.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Thou shalt have a wife, and a fruitful wife, for I find, Hylas,
That I shall never be able to bring thee children.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: A notable brave boy.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: I am very well sir.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Thou shalt be better Hylas thou hast seven hundred pound a year,
And thou shalt make her three hundred jointure.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Thou shalt boy, and shalt bestow
Two hundred pound in clothes, look on her,
A delicate lusty wench, she has fifteen hundred,
And feasible: strike hands, or I will strike first.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: You will let me like?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: He is a good handsome fellow,
Play not the fool.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Strike, brother, Hylas quickly.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: If you can love me, well.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: If you can please me.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Try that out soon, I say, my brother Hylas.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Take her, and use her well, she is a brave gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: You must allow me another Mistress.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Then you must allow me another Servant.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Well, let us together then, a lusty kindred.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I will give thee five hundred pound more for that word.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Now Sir, for you and I to make the feast full.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: No, not a bit, you are a virtuous Lady,
And love to live in contemplation.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Come fool, I am friends now.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: The fool shall not ride ye,
There lie my woman, now my man again,
And now for travel once more.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I will bar that first.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: And I next.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Hold yourself contented: for I say I will travel,
And so long I will travel, till I find a father
That never knew, and a wife that I never looked for,
And a state without expectation,
So rest you merry Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: You shall not
Upon my faith, I love you now extremely,
And now I will kiss ye.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: This will not do it, Mistress.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Why when we are married, we do more.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: There is all boy,
The keys of all I have, come, let us be merry,
For now I see thou art right.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Shall we to Church straight?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Now presently, and there with nuptial
The holy Priest shall make ye happy all.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Away then, fair afore.
